componenttext: First couple questions are focused on TXI, and in particular, for the quarter, what was the switch between Q3 and Q4 in terms of realizing the upside from TXI synergies? And to that end, what inning are we in terms of cost takeout for TXI?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kathryn, thank you for your question. I guess 2 components in that. Number one, you have to remember, when we went into the transaction and closed it on July 1 because of the antitrust process, our operating teams had really only had about a couple of wee
componenttext: Kathryn, thank you for your question. I guess 2 components in that. Number one, you have to remember, when we went into the transaction and closed it on July 1 because of the antitrust process, our operating teams had really only had about a couple of weeks with that business before we closed. So from a practical matter, their time on the ground and their time looking for what we find or what we term found synergies, was really pretty short. So what's happened is you're seeing really the result of having our teams and, therefore, more expanded period of time. That's what's really driven the acceleration of these synergies. So I'm not that surprised by it. I knew if we could get our good people on the ground, they would capture those, and we would see them quickly. And I do think they did a fantastic job with that. To the next part of your question, where are we in the innings? I think we're in the early innings of this game. Again, we've owned this business for a little bit over half a year. You're seeing that type of synergy realization that quickly. You have to assume that we use the combined workforce, and that's what we are now, will continue to work very effectively to find more. And I think you should expect us to find more.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: One other follow-up question on TXI. What were the -- could you remind me the total aggregate volumes for calendar 2014? And what is TXI earnings contributing to 2015 in terms of the guidance you outlined today?
componenttext: One other follow-up question on TXI. What were the -- could you remind me the total aggregate volumes for calendar 2014? And what is TXI earnings contributing to 2015 in terms of the guidance you outlined today?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: I can give you exactly what they were for the -- we're looking at 3.5 million tons of TXI really for the quarter. And that, that's stone side, we're looking at about 1.3 million on the cement side for the quarter, Kathryn. Again, the full year, we had nev
componenttext: I can give you exactly what they were for the -- we're looking at 3.5 million tons of TXI really for the quarter. And that, that's stone side, we're looking at about 1.3 million on the cement side for the quarter, Kathryn. Again, the full year, we had never gone back and had talked about that, but we're giving good guidance on that going forward.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. And in terms of the volumes-related synergy. In the past, you've said it was roughly 7 million tons related to the energy industry or regions specifically impacted by that. How much of the volumes -- 2 tiers, one, what are you seeing now in
componenttext: Okay, perfect. And in terms of the volumes-related synergy. In the past, you've said it was roughly 7 million tons related to the energy industry or regions specifically impacted by that. How much of the volumes -- 2 tiers, one, what are you seeing now in terms of trends? You alluded to that in your prepared commentary. And then the second half is how much of those volumes are more related to -- directly to the energy industry? So for instance, building out a pad versus any other type of construction projects which might be, for instance, building a road in a region that would be building road anyway but happens to be in the oil patch.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Here's what we saw in energy in the fourth quarter to give you a sense. We saw fourth quarter sale volumes of 1.7 million tons. That was down about 350,000 tons for the quarter. We saw a pullback in the Eagle Ford. Oddly enough, or maybe not oddly enough,
componenttext: Here's what we saw in energy in the fourth quarter to give you a sense. We saw fourth quarter sale volumes of 1.7 million tons. That was down about 350,000 tons for the quarter. We saw a pullback in the Eagle Ford. Oddly enough, or maybe not oddly enough, we saw Haynesville actually up. So what you're seeing is a little bit of a play on gas versus gas and oil, Kathryn. If we go back and look at the full year, it was around 7.5 million tons. You're just been dead on, on that. Most of that is going to either roads or pads or otherwise, but here's the take that we have on it. What we're seeing is a strong enough recovery in other areas of nonres that we think that's going to offset whatever bumps there may be in some elements of the product simply going to the different shale plays. So from where we're sitting, the shale play has always been in nonres all by itself. We're just seeing other portions of it that are growing so rapidly. We think it's likely to offset that. But the other piece of it, Kathryn, though, that I think is important is the way energy has been moving, particularly in a state like Texas. To put some metrics to it, we used, I want to say, 17 million gallons of diesel fuel in the Southwest last year. So as we're watching oil prices come down, can it affect some degree of volume going to channel [ph] fields, the answer is yes. Do I think it's going to be horribly dramatic? The answer to that is no. Do I think the cost benefit that we're likely to see from that is much better than the downside on the volume? The answer to that is absolutely.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: And last question. Touching on lower diesel. What was the benefit in the quarter if you can quantify that.
componenttext: And last question. Touching on lower diesel. What was the benefit in the quarter if you can quantify that.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kathryn, it was around $4 million for the quarter. To give you a sense of what a run rate is looking like, in Q3, we burned about 11.5 million gallons of diesel fuel; in Q4, about 10.4 million, and that goes back to heritage numbers. Q1 we were 6.4 millio
componenttext: Kathryn, it was around $4 million for the quarter. To give you a sense of what a run rate is looking like, in Q3, we burned about 11.5 million gallons of diesel fuel; in Q4, about 10.4 million, and that goes back to heritage numbers. Q1 we were 6.4 million and Q2 we were 8.5 million. So if we're looking at a run rate for this combined Martin Marietta TXI business, we're probably in that 40 million to 44 million gallons of diesel per year. That's not a bad way to think about it.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Trey Grooms with Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Trey Grooms with Stephens.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just kind of a follow-up on that -- the -- on the last question about energy. So if you look at your Texas business overall, what is the mix of -- is the mix of Texas any different than the mix that you have for your overall company that you outlined h
componenttext: So just kind of a follow-up on that -- the -- on the last question about energy. So if you look at your Texas business overall, what is the mix of -- is the mix of Texas any different than the mix that you have for your overall company that you outlined here?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it's not dramatically different. And the one thing that I would say that I think we need to think about is they've got a record letting program in Texas this year, Trey. So the simple fact is, if you look at a record infrastructure letting program thi
componenttext: No, it's not dramatically different. And the one thing that I would say that I think we need to think about is they've got a record letting program in Texas this year, Trey. So the simple fact is, if you look at a record infrastructure letting program this year, close to $10 billion, and then that doesn't include a lot of the P3 work that's going on in that state. From an infrastructure perspective, it's simply getting larger. And keep in mind, even the Energy Carter Road [ph] work that started last year, about $150 million worth of that work was let. But Texas will tell you they've got a $1 billion issue there all by themselves. So my point is this, more and more of that work, probably for the next 2, 3 years at least in Texas, will tend to be infrastructure-driven simply because that market is so immense right now.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: And so the comment that you made about seeing some areas of nonres, seeing them -- those areas grow rapidly, in your expectation to -- for those to offset any slowdown you would see in energy-related demand, can you talk more specifically about your -- wh
componenttext: And so the comment that you made about seeing some areas of nonres, seeing them -- those areas grow rapidly, in your expectation to -- for those to offset any slowdown you would see in energy-related demand, can you talk more specifically about your -- what you're seeing, where you're seeing those -- that rapid improvement?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Here's the quick way to think of it. It continues, in some respects, to be highly concentrated in Texas because if you're looking at nonresidential starts -- so these are projects that aren't completed. These are projects that are underway and starting --
componenttext: Here's the quick way to think of it. It continues, in some respects, to be highly concentrated in Texas because if you're looking at nonresidential starts -- so these are projects that aren't completed. These are projects that are underway and starting -- the change from 2013 to 2014 was nearly $17 billion. So you just got an enormous amount of activity in that marketplace that's moving in that fashion. At the same time, when we come back and take a look at more traditional commercial, in other words what's going on in office, what's going on in retail, what's going on in shopping centers, what we're seeing right now, Trey, is considerably more work in that space than we've seen over the last several years. What you'll remember is we've seen a lot of heavy work in nonres over the last 2 or 3 years but not a lot on the lighter side of commercial. Now we're starting to see that turn. But we're also starting to see that turn in other states that are important to us: South Carolina, up 14%; Colorado, up 17%. So again, very good nonres activity across the board.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then shifting gears on the share repurchase program. Are you guys expecting to fund the majority of that or all of it, or I guess, how much of it, with free cash flow versus are you thinking you may need to lever up some and bring on some debt t
componenttext: Okay. And then shifting gears on the share repurchase program. Are you guys expecting to fund the majority of that or all of it, or I guess, how much of it, with free cash flow versus are you thinking you may need to lever up some and bring on some debt to fund the buyback?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part and let Anne come back and give some color to that. But our view is we can do this using our excess free cash flow. So we can go through this, we can take care of the requirements of the business. We can take care of the requireme
componenttext: I'll take the first part and let Anne come back and give some color to that. But our view is we can do this using our excess free cash flow. So we can go through this, we can take care of the requirements of the business. We can take care of the requirements of the dividend. And as we come down to that targeted range of between 2 and 2.5, and as you heard in my opening remarks, we're now below 2.5, as we get toward that 2 range, Trey, if our projections are right, the free cash flow or excess free cash flow that this business is going to kick off is pretty considerable, and I think that's something that we've had a lot of conversations about. But Anne, do you want to add some color to that?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean I think the free cash flow alone could fund the program. Our view, however, is that you can preserve your leverage as your acquisition firepower. If you think, today, that a turn of leverage is $850 million, that can do some pretty good M&A ac
componenttext: Yes. I mean I think the free cash flow alone could fund the program. Our view, however, is that you can preserve your leverage as your acquisition firepower. If you think, today, that a turn of leverage is $850 million, that can do some pretty good M&A activity funding. So we would target that kind of 2x leverage, use all of our excess cash flow, assuming other capital priorities aren't there, and then -- and preserve our firepower for financial flexibility.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question is I guess a follow-up to the free cash flow generation that you're expecting over the next several years. Could you maybe talk about the CapEx requirements that you anticipate over the next, call it, 2 to 3 years? You identified a large pr
componenttext: First question is I guess a follow-up to the free cash flow generation that you're expecting over the next several years. Could you maybe talk about the CapEx requirements that you anticipate over the next, call it, 2 to 3 years? You identified a large project that you're putting into the budget for 2015. Does that go into 2016 and 2017? Or how should we think about CapEx, I guess, when we're putting that against some pretty strong free cash flow potential?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let's do this. Let me come back and talk about capital spending for this year. Anne will come back and talk a little bit more about CapEx in the out years. I mean, if we're looking at $320 million for this year, really the way that we're looking at that i
componenttext: Let's do this. Let me come back and talk about capital spending for this year. Anne will come back and talk a little bit more about CapEx in the out years. I mean, if we're looking at $320 million for this year, really the way that we're looking at that is probably around $184 million is in aggregates. We're seeing probably around $40 million in cement. As I mentioned in my comments, around $35 million on synergy. Around $28 million in ready-mix concrete. And then, of course, we're buying land and otherwise. Back to your very specific question, the Medina quarry project that we have outside of San Antonio, we're looking to put about $80 million into that this year, and we expect that project to be substantially complete this year. So we expect to turn the switch and have that process very much underway as we go into 2016.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the total spend on that Medina project is about $150 million, so we've already acquired the property and done initial work there. As we look at '16 and beyond, from a capital allocation perspective, we've put a placeholder in our forecasting of about
componenttext: And the total spend on that Medina project is about $150 million, so we've already acquired the property and done initial work there. As we look at '16 and beyond, from a capital allocation perspective, we've put a placeholder in our forecasting of about $350 million annually for the combined business. If you can look back over the pattern of our capital spending, Garik, we generally are countercyclical. When the markets are rising, recovery is rising, we generally are investing in Martin Marietta, expanding capacity, upgrading facilities. And then, generally, we do most of our M&A activity as the market is down.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Garik, one thing to remember there. As you remember, when we were really spending at a maintenance level, at that point we were looking at DD&A numbers closer to $175 million to $180 million. And we're looking at DD&A numbers today closer to $70 million,
componenttext: Garik, one thing to remember there. As you remember, when we were really spending at a maintenance level, at that point we were looking at DD&A numbers closer to $175 million to $180 million. And we're looking at DD&A numbers today closer to $70 million, just to put some scope to that.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, yes. I guess switching to cement and cement pricing. We saw a nice sequential increase in the second quarter of ownership of the TXI assets. Just wondering if you can help parse out, how much of the sequential price increase was just low-priced lega
componenttext: Okay, yes. I guess switching to cement and cement pricing. We saw a nice sequential increase in the second quarter of ownership of the TXI assets. Just wondering if you can help parse out, how much of the sequential price increase was just low-priced legacy projects rolling off so you had favorable project mix as opposed to organic price increases that were put into the market throughout the course of calendar '14?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Garik, it's tough to parse much of that. I can tell you, obviously, the older projects are rolling off now with pretty quick rapidity. Obviously, we came in and put a $10 a ton increase in that market. And Texas is a sold-out market, and then -- and we're
componenttext: Garik, it's tough to parse much of that. I can tell you, obviously, the older projects are rolling off now with pretty quick rapidity. Obviously, we came in and put a $10 a ton increase in that market. And Texas is a sold-out market, and then -- and we're going to do more of the same, and we've made that clear to our customers. And we're in very good places in that marketplace. So I would tell you, the older prices are rolling off, and what you're seeing going forward should be just true real sequential movement.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then my last question is with respect to your cost guidance. You've provided some of the sensitivities around diesel in your consumption, but your unit cost guidance is for a small decline. Just wondering how much of the potential diesel benefits you
componenttext: And then my last question is with respect to your cost guidance. You've provided some of the sensitivities around diesel in your consumption, but your unit cost guidance is for a small decline. Just wondering how much of the potential diesel benefits you do have embedded in your formal guidance for costs in 2015?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Garik, we have included, I would say, about $20 million of embedded diesel improvement in our forecast, and we actually think about when we do our planning. We do our planning in the October time frame, so we're going to use energy prices as of that time.
componenttext: Garik, we have included, I would say, about $20 million of embedded diesel improvement in our forecast, and we actually think about when we do our planning. We do our planning in the October time frame, so we're going to use energy prices as of that time. So there's been obviously a rapid decline from that point in time to the end of 2014. But we've kept that diesel price in our plan with all but about $20 million of that.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could talk about which chemicals and LNG projects are within your target markets in Texas and maybe you could outline which of them are via truck versus rail just to help us get an understanding of how you're positioned on those.
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could talk about which chemicals and LNG projects are within your target markets in Texas and maybe you could outline which of them are via truck versus rail just to help us get an understanding of how you're positioned on those.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll tell you what, I don't want to talk specific project by project. What I can tell you is we're looking in South Texas. They have 4 major energy projects. There's 1 major DOT project. And if I just look at those all by themselves, I can see the prospec
componenttext: I'll tell you what, I don't want to talk specific project by project. What I can tell you is we're looking in South Texas. They have 4 major energy projects. There's 1 major DOT project. And if I just look at those all by themselves, I can see the prospect of 2.5 million tons of aggregates on those. If we look at Houston, I can see 11 different projects there with well over 2 million tons required. Houston road projects, separate and distinct from those other private projects, 6 major road projects, over 4 million tons on those. And then back to the conversation we were having around infrastructure and specifically what's going on in North Texas, we're looking at projects in Dallas and Fort Worth in North Texas going to call for almost 9 million tons of aggregates. So these are big projects all over the state, big tonnage, and it makes us feel awfully good about where we are.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: And how long are the infrastructure projects? I guess we're hearing from some of the REITs around Texas that the new activity for them in 2016 will slow. And I'm wondering, do you have enough visibility on the public side to really drive growth into '16 o
componenttext: And how long are the infrastructure projects? I guess we're hearing from some of the REITs around Texas that the new activity for them in 2016 will slow. And I'm wondering, do you have enough visibility on the public side to really drive growth into '16 off of '15 at least based on what you see even if the private side slows?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I'm looking at I-65 -- 69 in Houston, just starting to supply the project on US-290 in Houston, just starting to supply the project on State Highway 288 in Houston. We're just starting to take bids on the Grand Parkway and another leg of it will be com
componenttext: If I'm looking at I-65 -- 69 in Houston, just starting to supply the project on US-290 in Houston, just starting to supply the project on State Highway 288 in Houston. We're just starting to take bids on the Grand Parkway and another leg of it will be coming out again in May. So a lot of these projects, Jerry, that I'm talking about are projects that have multiple years ahead of them, and they're just starting. So I'm not really speaking to jobs that I feel like could be going away in the near term. These are jobs that have legs to them.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I'm wondering if you could just talk about the pricing actions in cement and aggregates. I believe you're planning a significant increase on January 1 for aggregates in Texas. And then maybe you can comment on when did you notify customers
componenttext: Okay. And then I'm wondering if you could just talk about the pricing actions in cement and aggregates. I believe you're planning a significant increase on January 1 for aggregates in Texas. And then maybe you can comment on when did you notify customers of a next price increase in Texas cement. I think the general market expectation is for another round of increase around March. And I'm wondering, is that consistent with your schedule?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean that's the conversation we've certainly been having with customers. Again, going back to the conversation we had a minute ago. These are markets that, in large part, sold out. And DFW, in particular, is a market that's short on sand and a market th
componenttext: I mean that's the conversation we've certainly been having with customers. Again, going back to the conversation we had a minute ago. These are markets that, in large part, sold out. And DFW, in particular, is a market that's short on sand and a market that's long on really big projects. So we will certainly continue to push price along in these markets simply because of where they are and the effectiveness with which we can supply them.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: And would you care to comment on the magnitude of those price increase in aggregates and cement?
componenttext: And would you care to comment on the magnitude of those price increase in aggregates and cement?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. In cement, we're looking another $10 a ton in the Dallas -- in Texas markets. And in aggregates, in that marketplace, we came back at a midyear price increase in Dallas/Fort Worth last year. We're coming into this year. It's going to vary by product,
componenttext: Yes. In cement, we're looking another $10 a ton in the Dallas -- in Texas markets. And in aggregates, in that marketplace, we came back at a midyear price increase in Dallas/Fort Worth last year. We're coming into this year. It's going to vary by product, but you could be looking anywhere from on the low end of $0.50 a ton to a high end of -- closer tons to a couple bucks a ton.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of just the path to get to full utilization in the Texas cement operation I guess based on the bookings in hand, do you anticipate you'll be at full production rate in 2015? Can you just give us some more color there, please?
componenttext: And then in terms of just the path to get to full utilization in the Texas cement operation I guess based on the bookings in hand, do you anticipate you'll be at full production rate in 2015? Can you just give us some more color there, please?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we'll continue to drive toward full production rate. Here's what full production rate is going to look like for us, Jerry. We're looking to be at 7 million tons by 2017. So here's the way that I would think about it. We're going to look in 2015 to
componenttext: I think we'll continue to drive toward full production rate. Here's what full production rate is going to look like for us, Jerry. We're looking to be at 7 million tons by 2017. So here's the way that I would think about it. We're going to look in 2015 to add probably 250,000 tons in Texas. That should be about 200,000 tons at Hunter and 50,000 at Midlothian. In 2016, looking to come back and add another 300,000 tons, probably about 140,000 at Hunter, 160,000 at Midlothian. And by 2017, looking to add another probably 250,000 tons in Texas. That's going to give you your bridge to what we say is 7 in 2017.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Jerry, just as a reminder. You don't just get those efficiencies at the drop of hat. You have to work through them as you go through planned outages at the various plants and facilities.
componenttext: And Jerry, just as a reminder. You don't just get those efficiencies at the drop of hat. You have to work through them as you go through planned outages at the various plants and facilities.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe you just say a bit more on that last point, just calibrate us on how we should think about seasonality for the cement business '15 versus '14. You had a very good fourth quarter despite the maintenance work. Can you just help us understand
componenttext: Okay. And maybe you just say a bit more on that last point, just calibrate us on how we should think about seasonality for the cement business '15 versus '14. You had a very good fourth quarter despite the maintenance work. Can you just help us understand which are the seasonally weaker versus stronger quarters in '15 since the TXI reporting was a bit off schedule from yours?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jerry, it's really going to be more driven, to Anne's point, when the outages are. So if you look at total outages in 2014, we had about $30.5 million spent at the cement operations in 2014. I think you should expect similar costs, call it a little bit no
componenttext: Jerry, it's really going to be more driven, to Anne's point, when the outages are. So if you look at total outages in 2014, we had about $30.5 million spent at the cement operations in 2014. I think you should expect similar costs, call it a little bit north of $31 million in '15. So what we're looking at is, in Q2 and Q4, we're probably looking at major outages. In Q1 and Q3, we're looking at smaller outages. So the way that I would say a major outage, define that as something that's in the zip code of plus $4 million and a small outage somewhere being between $1 million and $2 million.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you look at -- and the $30 million number that Ward gave you for '14 was obviously annualized. We didn't incur $30 million in the second half of 2014. So the TXI business had $30 million of calendar 2014 outages. We expect $31 million in '15.
componenttext: Yes. If you look at -- and the $30 million number that Ward gave you for '14 was obviously annualized. We didn't incur $30 million in the second half of 2014. So the TXI business had $30 million of calendar 2014 outages. We expect $31 million in '15.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Keith Hughes with SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Keith Hughes with SunTrust.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Wanted to address this in a couple of days at the Analyst Day but was intrigued with your question of using cash flow to fund this repurchase program. Is that something you're going to cover? I'm not going to make you go over the numbers on the call, but,
componenttext: Wanted to address this in a couple of days at the Analyst Day but was intrigued with your question of using cash flow to fund this repurchase program. Is that something you're going to cover? I'm not going to make you go over the numbers on the call, but, generally, how are you going to get there? I'm having a hard time with the math.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I don't have your model in front of me, but just based on our view of the cash flow projections of the business, you've got to take into consideration the minimal cash taxes that we will be paying over the next 2 years. We believe that there'll be
componenttext: I mean, I don't have your model in front of me, but just based on our view of the cash flow projections of the business, you've got to take into consideration the minimal cash taxes that we will be paying over the next 2 years. We believe that there'll be sufficient excess free cash flow to generate the $1 billion to $2 billion over the next 3 years that we would need to execute against this repurchase. So we can talk more about details.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Keith, [indiscernible] another piece of that as well. We did identify excess properties at TXI. And as we come through and sell those excess properties, too, that will play into this.
componenttext: Keith, [indiscernible] another piece of that as well. We did identify excess properties at TXI. And as we come through and sell those excess properties, too, that will play into this.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have an estimate of what those are going to be?
componenttext: Do you have an estimate of what those are going to be?

componenttextpreview: We talked about them at the time of the transactions that they'd be $100 million, plus/minus.
componenttext: We talked about them at the time of the transactions that they'd be $100 million, plus/minus.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that hasn't changed, your view hasn't changed?
componenttext: So that hasn't changed, your view hasn't changed?

componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and second question. You've got some very bullish nonresidential discussions here. We talked a lot about Gulf Coast and Texas construction. Is there any other areas of nonresidential that you feel will be improving in 2015 versus what you saw in 201
componenttext: Okay, and second question. You've got some very bullish nonresidential discussions here. We talked a lot about Gulf Coast and Texas construction. Is there any other areas of nonresidential that you feel will be improving in 2015 versus what you saw in 2014?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think what we're seeing is we're seeing it across the enterprise now, Keith, because what's happened, and you've seen it, too, in Atlanta and other markets, that's going to tend to follow housing with a lag. And in markets that you're seeing good employ
componenttext: I think what we're seeing is we're seeing it across the enterprise now, Keith, because what's happened, and you've seen it, too, in Atlanta and other markets, that's going to tend to follow housing with a lag. And in markets that you're seeing good employment dynamics, and now you've got North Carolina and Georgia and Florida, all with good employment dynamics, all with much better housing dynamics. And now what we're seeing is we're seeing the change on nonres moving in those states exactly as we would have anticipated. So we continue to see strong momentum and growth in markets like Texas, good momentum and growth in markets like Colorado, increasing momentum and better growth in markets like Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina and Florida.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ted Grace with Susquehanna.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ted Grace with Susquehanna.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could just to talk about kind of the 2015 EBITDA guidance and really focus on the core aggregates business. Either Anne or Ward, can you just walk through kind of how you'd encourage people to think about the flow-through rate just for th
componenttext: I was hoping you could just to talk about kind of the 2015 EBITDA guidance and really focus on the core aggregates business. Either Anne or Ward, can you just walk through kind of how you'd encourage people to think about the flow-through rate just for the aggregates business? I mean, you've helped dimensionalize what diesel dynamics will be, but from the standpoint of kind of when we normally think about, call it, 50% to 60% flow-through rates for the core business x pricing, and you said that over normalize. You've never said that that's kind of the target in a given year. But could you just give us a little handholding kind of either how people should be thinking about '15 and/or the key variables to get you between $825 million and $875 million. Is that volume-dependent more than anything? Is it synergy-dependent more than anything? Just, to a degree, can you kind of flesh that out? That would be great.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the primary thing I think some of that is, I think synergy certainly helps with that. I think the more powerful element of that really is when you're coming back and you're starting to see the Eastern United States perform a little bit better. I mea
componenttext: Well, the primary thing I think some of that is, I think synergy certainly helps with that. I think the more powerful element of that really is when you're coming back and you're starting to see the Eastern United States perform a little bit better. I mean, here's the way that you can think about it. We actually, for the full year, in the Mid-Atlantic division, sold less tonnage in '14 than we sold in '13. Now we're seeing that market get much stronger going into '15, made more money in Mid-Atlantic on less tonnage in '14 than we did in '13. So our point is simply this, with that type of volume momentum now in those markets and with that type of performance in those markets, we feel like that can be awfully powerful to this business. And again, what we're seeing particularly in North Texas around infrastructure, we think is a great story. And again, to your point, we're seeing lower occupancy rates in nonres than we've seen in Dallas in close to a decade right now. So when we look at what's going on in sold-outs in that market, what we can do with pricing in that market, but to your point, what we can do in aggregates with synergies in TXI and emerging strength in the Southeast and the mid-Atlantic group that's performing more strongly, that's the key to it. That's the part of the country, as you know, Ted, that has been the slowest to come out of this. And that's the part of the country that's the most disproportionately profitable for us, particularly in heritage aggregates when it's performing in a more normalized way.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: If we look at the kind of the bookends of $825 million, $875 million, Ted, I mean, obviously, wherever energy costs land for the course of the year -- if energy costs were to stay exactly as they were at the end of 2014 throughout the course of 2015, that
componenttext: If we look at the kind of the bookends of $825 million, $875 million, Ted, I mean, obviously, wherever energy costs land for the course of the year -- if energy costs were to stay exactly as they were at the end of 2014 throughout the course of 2015, that $275 million number is pretty easily achievable. Pricing, up or down, one way or the other, and then really it's back to Ward's point. It's the improvement that we began to see in the back half of the year in that Southern -- South or Southern -- lower right quartile of the United States. If that continues, I think you can see a stronger recovery in that EBITDA line.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: True, true. So my second question would be, just following up on a couple others. I mean, we're the second-highest estimates on The Street, and I understand and appreciate kind of the tax shield related to the NOL, but cumulatively, we have you generating
componenttext: True, true. So my second question would be, just following up on a couple others. I mean, we're the second-highest estimates on The Street, and I understand and appreciate kind of the tax shield related to the NOL, but cumulatively, we have you generating like $1.7 billion of cash over the next 3 years which, based on your comment, sounds too low. I know you talked about $1 billion to $2 billion of free cash, but you're talking about, at $135, that's $2.7 billion in buybacks. So I think that's what we're trying to struggle with that math. Could you -- so I guess the question is, are you actually implicitly telling us at the midpoint, you said $1 billion to $2 billion of free cash, it's really more like $2.5 billion is what you're thinking to generate if you can fund this whole thing organically? Or does that include asset sales beyond the $100 million, I mean, Oro Grande, if you were to sell that or lever it? I guess that's what kind of I think people are trying to square up today as you're talking about buying back $2.7 billion of stock at today's market price, and what you've outlined is not a big cash number that is even close to $2.7 billion. So maybe can you just talk about that a little more to help us understand it?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ted, when we do our valuation of $1 billion to $2 billion of share buybacks, if you recall, I mean this stock price can't happen today. So the $133 mark got hit today. So we looked at $1 billion to $2 billion buyback that we thought we could generate that
componenttext: Ted, when we do our valuation of $1 billion to $2 billion of share buybacks, if you recall, I mean this stock price can't happen today. So the $133 mark got hit today. So we looked at $1 billion to $2 billion buyback that we thought we could generate that cash flow. And at the market price before today, that very easily got 20 million shares, right. But obviously, we'll reassess and evaluate. We have said that it's the excess free cash flow that we would generate from the business after organic capital and dividends. We'll add back any proceeds from nonstrategic nonoperating asset sales for TXI, and that would be what we would deploy for share repurchases.

And that is what we had believed that we could allocate to share repurchases over the next 2 to 3 years.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ward, just back on the quarter, the 12% increase from the infrastructure end market in Q4, was the majority of that from Texas? Or is it kind of evenly distributed among kind of Colorado, Florida, but some of the other markets you talked about?
componenttext: Ward, just back on the quarter, the 12% increase from the infrastructure end market in Q4, was the majority of that from Texas? Or is it kind of evenly distributed among kind of Colorado, Florida, but some of the other markets you talked about?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: It was relatively evenly distributed. I mean, here's what we've got -- I mean, if you're looking in North Carolina, I mean, we're seeing some good projects that are underway and some good projects that are coming. I mean, in particular, we're seeing some
componenttext: It was relatively evenly distributed. I mean, here's what we've got -- I mean, if you're looking in North Carolina, I mean, we're seeing some good projects that are underway and some good projects that are coming. I mean, in particular, we're seeing some work coming up in Charlotte and work coming up in Greensboro. But again, we saw better infrastructure work in North Carolina than we've seen for a while. Georgia, remember, as you well know, the T Plus [ph] program has put $1.8 billion over 10 years in South Georgia primarily. So now that's starting to pull through to a degree. The Florida program, as you referenced, is really very, very strong. I mean, it's the largest DOT budget in that state's history. One thing that's important about a state like Florida, and I think it's a good model for the rest of the country, less than 30% of their DOT money actually originates from federal coffers, which gives that a nice staying power all the way through. And of course, Colorado, as we discussed, has a good DOT program supplemented by their RAMP program, supplemented by a lot of FEMA spending in that marketplace right now. So you've got a series of markets in addition to what's going on in Texas that have actually done quite well as you recall. When we actually gave guidance last year at this same time for 2014, we anticipated the infrastructure would be up, and I think really a lot of people had some skepticism about it at the time, and we said where you are really matters on these DOT programs. And that's exactly what happened in '14. That's what we think is going to happen in '15 as well.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think depending on the timing of these large projects, I think that is probably the case. And the other thing that I would tell you is if we can come through with a multiyear highway bill, I think in some respects, that could change everything. Remember
componenttext: I think depending on the timing of these large projects, I think that is probably the case. And the other thing that I would tell you is if we can come through with a multiyear highway bill, I think in some respects, that could change everything. Remember, we've been doing this, in many respects, living hand to mouth on a DOT program for the better part of a decade. We haven't had a clear run on a multiyear bill. And if we get a multiyear bill, then I think you're clearly looking at something that we put out that's a very, very safe number, and it would likely be popped up. And part of what I'm encouraged by is, right now, when you've got members of the Tea Party like Rand Paul looking hard to find a way to put a multiyear bill out there, that -- I think that gives us a pretty good sense of where the year may be going.

componenttextpreview: I think the primary thing that's happening, SG&A numbers haven't changed. What's gotten more robust, procurement has gotten more robust, operations has gotten more robust. So those are the primary areas that you would imagine. If you think about it in the
componenttext: I think the primary thing that's happening, SG&A numbers haven't changed. What's gotten more robust, procurement has gotten more robust, operations has gotten more robust. So those are the primary areas that you would imagine. If you think about it in these terms, the 2 big quarries that we picked up, the Bridgeport operation that is literally next door to our Chico operation, and their Mill Creek operation -- and cleverly, our Mill Creek operation, literally next door to each other, those can now operate as single quarries. And the efficiencies that we're getting from that, operationally and otherwise, are very significant in addition to procurement. So basically the markers that we put down on SG&A and otherwise that we knew we would be getting, they've done exactly as we would have thought. The operational side of it has come through better, has come through faster.

componenttext: We'll give you a good readout of it on a quarter-by-quarter basis. A lot of it's going to depend on how the underlying business is performing. A lot of it is going to depend on what opportunities are out there as well because the primary thing that we want to make sure we do is create value. And buying share backs creates value. Doing the right transaction creates value as well. So it may not be a perfectly linear buyback. You shouldn't expect it to be. But we will come back, and we'll tell you quarterly what it looks like.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Martin Marietta First Quarter 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Wa
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Martin Marietta First Quarter 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ward Nye, Chairman and CEO. Mr. Nye, please go ahead.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining Martin Marietta's quarterly earnings call. With me today is Anne Lloyd, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.As announced in this morning's release, we reported a first quarter profit for the
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining Martin Marietta's quarterly earnings call. With me today is Anne Lloyd, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
As announced in this morning's release, we reported a first quarter profit for the first time since 2008, another validation of our recent growth initiatives and cost management programs. Our results reflect aggregates product line volume growth and a double-digit pricing increase, which we achieved despite severe late winter weather in many markets and significant rainfall in Texas, which we estimate reduced West Group earnings by $13 million or $0.12 per diluted share. The Magnesia Specialties business generated first quarter record net sales and gross profit, and the acquired operations provided significant contributions to our earnings and cash flow.
Before providing specific comments on the quarter, I'm pleased to tell you that the foundation, position and momentum within our business should translate into strong growth as we expect to benefit from an environment of increasing demand for construction materials.
As a preparatory reminder, today's conference may include forward-looking statements as defined by securities laws in connection with future events or future operating or financial performance. Like other businesses, we're subject to risks and uncertainties which could cause actual results to differ materially. Except as legally required, we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether resulting from new information, future developments or otherwise. We refer you to the legal disclaimers contained in our first quarter earnings release and to our other filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which are available on both our own and the SEC websites.
Also, any margin references in our discussion are based on net sales and exclude freight and delivery revenues. These and other non-GAAP measures are also explained in our SEC filings and on our website.
Consistent with recent quarters, I'll discuss the results for the heritage business separately from those of the acquired operations, which include the legacy TXI business and 2 other small aggregates product line operations. While it's currently important to consider the results of heritage versus acquired operations so that we're fully transparent with our results and you can analyze and evaluate the quality of our financial performance, this comparison becomes less meaningful as we complete the integration of the TXI operations into our core business. In addition, we facilitate this discussion we've made available during this webcast and on our website supplemental financial information that presents details of our performance. First, as detailed on Slide 2, the heritage Martin Marietta business, which includes Magnesia Specialties, provides a same-on-same comparison to the prior year first quarter. Next, the results of the acquired operations, by product line and in total, are provided on Slide 4. And finally, on Slide 6, we provide an analysis of the increase in earnings from operations. We believe this approach provides meaningful information to better analyze our current performance.
Now let's review some of the underlying transfer for the heritage business. Slide 3 provides volume and pricing metrics by product line of the heritage aggregates business. First, we're pleased to report pricing growth across our entire company. It's important to note that the prior year first quarter includes shipments from the 3 facilities in the West Group that were divested in the third quarter of 2014. Consequently, to obtain true comparable volume variances, shipments from these 3 locations should be excluded from the prior year quarter. After making this adjustment, West Group volumes were up slightly, while shipments from the heritage aggregates business increased 7%. Further, and as you are aware, our business is an outdoor undertaking, and weather can disproportionately affect quarterly results, particularly so in the first quarter. On the whole, winter weather was modestly better across our enterprise during the early portion of the quarter as compared to last year. However, Texas precipitation this year was above average, near record levels, according to the National Climatic Data Center. In fact, we estimate approximately 1.4 million tons of aggregates product line shipments were deferred from the first quarter to the remainder of the year. Heritage West Group aggregate volumes, excluding shipments from the divested operations from the prior year quarter, would've increased approximately 7.5%, had we not incurred weather delays. Ready-mixed concrete shipments were reduced by approximately 200,000 cubic yards. Naturally, profitability from this product lines was also negatively affected by lower production and efficiency levels. As previously discussed, we estimate West Group earnings were reduced by up to $13 million during the quarter. Despite these headwinds, our commitment to operational excellence, cost discipline and continued synergy realization from the acquired businesses enabled us to post a very strong quarter.
Aggregates product line growth was led by the infrastructure end-use markets and driven by large projects. Notable growth was experienced in North Carolina and Iowa. This trend coincides with indicators of further recovery in the eastern half of the United States as North Carolina, Georgia and Florida all now ranked in the top 5 states for job growth, a clear stimulus for construction activity. Texas is second in the nation in job growth, and the State Department of Transportation has a fiscal 2015 budget of nearly $9 billion. This amount includes funds provided by Texas's proposition 1 constitutional amendment, which addresses needed road repairs, including infrastructure work in South Texas. This amendment is expected to provide over $1 billion per annum for the foreseeable future. And in fact, over $1 billion has already been allocated to specific districts within Texas. This 2015 activity, coupled with an existing backlog, should generate robust infrastructure construction activity over the next several years. Additionally on March 1, 2015, Iowa enacted a $0.10 per gallon increase in state gas tax, which is expected to increase annual infrastructure funding by approximately $215 million. Several other states, including North Carolina and Georgia, are considering additional legislative measures to increase state-level funding.
We're pleased to see states continue to prioritize funding infrastructure initiatives, while Congress deliberates a long-term federal highway bill. The provisions of the Moving Ahead for Progress in the 21st Century Act or MAP-21 have been extended through May 31, and we anticipate another continuing resolution through the fall of Congress works toward passage of a multiyear bill. Shipments to the nonresidential end-use market were up slightly as the economic recovery enters a more construction-centric phase. For us, this market is broadly comprised of 2 components, light and heavy construction. And importantly, we're beginning to see a nascent return to a 50-50 balance between these 2 categories, a normal equilibrium. Light nonresidential component is primarily office and retail, and demand of this component is generally tied more directly to residential demand with a 12- to 18-month lag. The heavy component is primarily industrial building in energy, with both direct and energy-related shipments serving this area. The heavy nonresidential end-use market represented 25% of quarterly heritage aggregates volumes, and shipments increased 1% over the prior year quarter. Texas leads the country with $39 billion in nonresidential starts during the trailing 12 months ended March 2015 and billions more expected to be started. Further, diversified state economies have generated other nonresidential and infrastructure projects to replace direct energy sector shipments currently displaced by volatile oil prices. The company expects energy-related construction activity to remain strong, supported by more than $100 billion of plant projects along the Gulf coast, including a significant portion in Texas. The residential end-use market represented 15% of heritage aggregates shipments and increased 4% compared with the prior year quarter. The overall rate of residential growth has slowed compared with the last few years, in part due to an inventory reduction and the availability of unimproved building lots in our markets. We were encouraged to see Georgia, Florida and South Carolina join Colorado in reporting double-digit growth in housing starts for the trailing 12 months through March. This represents yet another sign of recovery in the Eastern United States.
Finally, to conclude discussion of end-use markets for the first quarter, the ChemRock and rail market represented the remaining 11% of our heritage aggregates volume, and shipments were up slightly compared to the prior year quarter. A positive trend for this end-use is the increasing investment in capacity expansion and maintenance by major railroads, which should lead to higher demand for ballast shipments.
Heritage aggregates product line pricing increased 10.5% over the prior year quarter, led by the West Group. Based on what we're expecting for the remainder of the year, we're raising full year aggregates product line pricing guidance from what was a projected increase of 4% to 6% to now an increase of 7% to 9% over our 2014 results. Heritage aggregates product line total production cost per ton shipped remained relatively flat compared with the prior year quarter. We continue to benefit from the decline in diesel prices, and on average, paid $2.04 per gallon compared with $3.18 in the prior year quarter.
Heritage aggregates downstream-related product lines increased their combined gross profit by $3 million, primarily driven by the ready-mixed concrete product line, where nearly 11% increase in average selling price led to a 490 basis point increase in the product line gross margin.
Gross profit for the heritage aggregates business increased $27 million and was 9.7% of net sales, improvement of 703 basis points over the prior year quarter. All reportable segments generated a higher gross margin, led by an increase of 1,040 basis points in the Southeast Group. Continued economic recovery in Georgia and better performance by our offshore operations contributed to this improvement. Our heritage business generated an incremental gross margin of 76%, besting our incremental margin target of 60%. This performance was led by long-awaited recovery in both in the Mid-East and Southeast divisions. We expect continued economic recovery in other geographic areas hardest hit over the past several years.
The Magnesia Specialties business continues its exceptional performance and generated net sales of $58.8 million and a gross profit of $20.2 million, both of which represent first quarter records. For the quarter, the business achieved a gross margin of 34.3%, an increase of 160 basis points over the prior year quarter.
Slides 4 and 5 provide financial information and key metrics for our acquired operations. In the first quarter, the acquired aggregates product line reported net sales of nearly $32 million on external shipments of 2.5 million tons. Average selling price was $12.83 per ton, which reflects the product mix skewed towards higher-priced sand and gravel and rail yard shipments compared to our heritage operations. Despite the negative impact of weather during the quarter, we're pleased to deliver gross margin improvement compared with the performance in the second half of 2014. Our recently acquired ready-mixed concrete business shipped nearly 1 million cubic yards during the quarter at an average selling price of $88.75. This reflects a $6 per cubic yard increase implemented last August in the North Texas market. As a reminder, pricing increases typically have a 6-month lag before full realization. As indicated earlier, weather constraints during the quarter adversely affected operations and reduced the profitability of this business by an estimated $6 million.
The Cement business is benefiting from continued strength in our Texas markets where demand is expected to exceed local supply again this year. However, first quarter operating results were negatively affected by wet weather, which delayed some shipments to the balance of the year. For the first quarter, the business shipped 1 million tons of cement to external customers at an average selling price of $93.41, resulting in net sales of more than $96 million. The business achieved a gross margin of nearly 20% after incurring $5.5 million of plant kiln and maintenance costs. We expect to incur $2 million of some of our costs in the second quarter, with $11 million and $10 million of such expenses in both the third and fourth quarters, respectively.
During the first quarter, the company announced a price increase of $10 per ton in the Texas and California markets, effective April 1.
Our consolidated selling, general and administrative or SG&A expenses were 7.8% of net sales, a decline of 120 basis points. This improvement reflects net sales growth outpacing the increase in SG&A, partially offset by higher pension expense. We also incurred net acquisition-related expenses of $1.6 million, which reflects our estimated run rate for the next few quarters.
As detailed on Slide 6, our reported earnings from operations for the quarter of $25.6 million improved $41.5 million from the prior year quarter loss of $15.9 million. Our synergy expectations are consistent with our most recent guidance. We did complete the systems integration for the Cement and ready-mixed concrete businesses during the second quarter, in line with our integration plan. We recorded a small income tax benefit in the quarter driven by discrete events. However, excluding discrete events, our effective income tax rate would've been 31%, in line with our full year guidance. For the year, we expect a fully utilized allowable net operating loss carryforwards of $363 million, which will reduce cash taxes.
For the quarter, we generated $35 million of operating cash flow compared with $7 million for 2014. The increase is due to higher earnings before depreciation, depletion and amortization expense, partially offset by higher cash taxes paid in the first quarter of 2015 for the 2014 tax year. The ratio of consolidated debt to consolidated EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ended March 31, 2015, was slightly less than 2.5x, in compliance with our leverage covenant and within our targeted range. As a reminder, we have board authorization to repurchase up to 20 million shares of our common stock. We expect to complete the program over the next 2 [ph] years. However, the actual timing will depend on available cash and market price of our stock during the time frame.
Moving to our full year guidance. We anticipate growth in nearly all of our markets, both geographically, particularly in areas with stronger employment gains and construction end-use. Further, we expect economic expansion in the Western United States to continue, and importantly, the economic recovery in the East to accelerate. Overall, in our geographies, we expect growth in our 3 largest end-use markets. Infrastructure market is expected to increase in the mid-single digits. Nonresidential construction is expected to increase in the high single digits. The residential market is expected to experience a double-digit increase, and the ChemRock/Rail market is expected to remain relatively flat. Cumulatively, we expect aggregates product line shipments to increase 10% to 12% with 4% to 7% growth in the heritage business and the remainder coming from a full year of owning the TXI operations. Again, we expect aggregates product line pricing to now be up 7% to 9% over 2014. Aggregates product line production cost per ton shipped is expected to decline slightly compared with 2014. The aggregates-related downstream operations are expected to generate between $875 million and $925 million of net sales and $65 million to $70 million of gross profit. We expect net sales for the Smith business to range from $475 million to $500 million and gross profit to be $120 million to $130 million. The Magnesia Specialties net sales are expected to be between $240 million and $250 million, generating a gross profit of $85 million to $90 million. SG&A expenses as a percentage of net sales are expected to be less than 6%, despite an $18 million increase in heritage pension costs over 2014. On a consolidated basis, we expect to generate earnings before interest, income taxes, depreciation, depletion and amortization expense or EBITDA ranging from $835 million to $875 million. Interest expense should approximate $75 million to $80 million, and the effective income tax rate is expected to be 31%, excluding discrete events. Capital expenditures are forecast to be $320 million, which includes $35 million of synergy-related capital and $80 million for the continued development of the new Medina limestone quarry outside of San Antonio. This capital project will provide a modern and highly efficient rail-connected quarry capable of shipping products to South Texas, including Houston, for generations.
To conclude, we are very excited about future of Martin Marietta Materials. Our commitment to core foundational pillars of world-class safety, operational excellence, cost discipline, ethical conduct, sustainability and customer satisfaction, along with the growing demand for construction materials, should lead to improved profitability and allow us to continue to increase shareholder value. If the operator will now give the required instructions, we'll turn our attention to addressing your questions.

componenttextpreview: Part of what you're seeing, Todd, is you're seeing that southeast part of the United States come back, but you heard what those incrementals look like in a state like Georgia. So you're entirely right. Does this pricing help? Yes, it does. Does cost manag
componenttext: Part of what you're seeing, Todd, is you're seeing that southeast part of the United States come back, but you heard what those incrementals look like in a state like Georgia. So you're entirely right. Does this pricing help? Yes, it does. Does cost management help? Yes, it does. Does geographic mix, where you're starting to see some business come back, help a lot? It does. I mean let's talk a little bit about what we saw relative to our production analysis just on the cost side. I mean, the pricing side, I think you can see with greater clarity. But we're looking at total heritage aggregates cost per ton, they declined 17% or 2% after adjusting for increased production volumes. What we did, Todd, is we were able to fully capture a 36% decline per gallon in diesel cost during the quarter, but we saw heritage production volume go up 12% or 2.9 million tons. So what's happening at the end of the day, separate and distinct from what's going on in pricing, is each incremental ton was produced at 20% lower than it was in 2014 from a natural cost per ton. So you're what you're seeing on both sides of the equation, the pricing, I think, from the release really jumps out and hits you in the face. But I think what's happening on the cost side is what's happening geographically is important in that 76% as well.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's great. And then one other and then I'll give other people a chance to ask a question. You talked about a pickup in subdivision development. Can you go into that a little more? And is there -- any quantifying you can do around that as we tal
componenttext: Got it. That's great. And then one other and then I'll give other people a chance to ask a question. You talked about a pickup in subdivision development. Can you go into that a little more? And is there -- any quantifying you can do around that as we talk about basis with that strengthening up?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, we're clearly seeing better housing in the east and we're seeing profile. I mean, here -- housing is completely following the playbook that we thought we'd see. Permanents were up 5%. Starts were up 10%. Completions at 12%. But here, the stats tha
componenttext: I mean, we're clearly seeing better housing in the east and we're seeing profile. I mean, here -- housing is completely following the playbook that we thought we'd see. Permanents were up 5%. Starts were up 10%. Completions at 12%. But here, the stats that move me. Permanents are ahead of starts. Starts are ahead of completions. And even when we're sitting here with those types of metrics, housing still remains well below historical averages. So if I think it gives us a great deal of upside. What we're seeing, too, is it's been fueled by employment gains. So if you go back to those states that we outlined in my comments where we're seeing good employment movement, North Carolina, Georgia, South Carolina, Florida, that's what's driving a lot of that. The other thing that I'm moved by, Todd, is a very tepid recovery in housing has really spurred pricing that we can imagine what a really, good market in housing is going to look like. But that's what we're seeing right now, Todd.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on that. Am I right to think in that subdivision development is sort of a lot steadier and longer-tailed than more sort of specifically related to lot development or what goes on in the house?
componenttext: Just a follow-up on that. Am I right to think in that subdivision development is sort of a lot steadier and longer-tailed than more sort of specifically related to lot development or what goes on in the house?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It is. One, it's a good in early indicator. Two, it's longer-lived. Three, it's aggregate-intensive. Because remember Todd, when we talk about res, we're not just talking about the rock going into lot development. We're talking about the lot going into th
componenttext: It is. One, it's a good in early indicator. Two, it's longer-lived. Three, it's aggregate-intensive. Because remember Todd, when we talk about res, we're not just talking about the rock going into lot development. We're talking about the lot going into the subdivision streets, the subdivision sidewalks, the subdivision utilities. That's part of what drives the comment that I said about moving to a more construction-centric phase of recovery. And that clearly is moving toward more subdivision development. Yes.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question I had is around energy in Texas. Just for practical purposes, the volumes that were impacted by weather, particularly in March, either it was delayed or lost? And then the second tag that's related to Texas, could you give more color around
componenttext: First question I had is around energy in Texas. Just for practical purposes, the volumes that were impacted by weather, particularly in March, either it was delayed or lost? And then the second tag that's related to Texas, could you give more color around trends that you've seen for shale play-specific volumes. And in your opinion, how prop 1 or will prop 1 more than enough to offset those volume losses that were going to have build-out?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Kathryn. Volume was in Q1 is not done, it's deferred. And it's deferred to the balance of year. So I feel comfortable we'll capture all of that. And clearly, a lot of that was driven by rain. I mean, I don't want to turn into a weather man here toda
componenttext: Sure, Kathryn. Volume was in Q1 is not done, it's deferred. And it's deferred to the balance of year. So I feel comfortable we'll capture all of that. And clearly, a lot of that was driven by rain. I mean, I don't want to turn into a weather man here today, but I look at something to me that I thought was moving on how weather affected particularly North Texas. If we look at water reservoirs in North Texas a year ago, they were 68% full. If we look at where they were 3 months ago, they were 64% full. And if we look at where they are today, they're 94% full. I mean, that's a remarkable rate in North Texas. That's what, among other things, gives me confidence. That volume's been pushing to that. That volume it's gone. And what we are seeing in nonres and other parts of Texas continues to be very strong. We feel comfortable that whatever weakness we're seeing in shale energy gas will be picked up by housing, and gas will be picked up by other components of nonres. And to answer your question really directed on what we're seeing relative to shale. It's in an even story. I mean, here's what I see. I see volumes down in the first quarter in Eagle Ford Shale, 31%. I see volumes up in Haynesville 142%. Now the short answer is do I think they're going to be down overall, just pure shale volumes? Yes, I do. But here's my take on it, Kathryn. I think they're going to look a lot like they did in 2012. And in 2012, all rolled in, we sold about 6 million tons to the different shale plays. And when I think back to 2012, number one, everybody liked the way 2012 felt. And nobody really thought they'd be that good. So that we think it'll be back into 2012 level in '15? We do. Are we seeing uneven movements in some the plays? We are. Do we think that volumes that was lost in Q1 were simply deferred? We do. I think I answered your questions. Is that responsive?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015

componenttext: Yes, yes. And then my final follow-up question, just around guidance. Fantastic growth in pricing. Or is there any other factor that we should take into consideration for that EBITDA?

componenttext: You know, it's funny, Timna. If I look across our enterprise, prices are up everywhere, and prices are up everywhere. There's some places that pricing is up over 30%. componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. So just switching gears to cement and resting on the topic. And you announced the price hike you said for April. You mentioned specifically that Texas is tight. componenttextpreview: We're certainly going to come back, and we're going to look at more [indiscernible] pricing as we get into the year. What I can tell you right now, up through Q1, Cement pricing in North Texas was up 11%. And in South Texas, it was up 19%. In California,
componenttext: We're certainly going to come back, and we're going to look at more [indiscernible] pricing as we get into the year. What I can tell you right now, up through Q1, Cement pricing in North Texas was up 11%. And in South Texas, it was up 19%. In California, it was up 15%. So to your point, those are pretty nice percentage moves that we're seeing in pricing in those markets. And again, we're at a leading position in Texas markets. But even where we have the leading positions, I think it's important. This is not a West Texas Cement play. This is a North Texas and the South Central Texas cement play. And so we continue to feel very confident about where we sit in pricing those markets.

componenttext: It's not as tight a market as Texas is. I certainly can see that, and the total pricing isn't right now as attractive as it is Texas. But from a percentage perspective, frankly, it's moving somewhere in a percentage perspective between where it is South Texas and where it is in North Texas right now. And I think that's a good sign for a market moving toward a very steady fashion equilibrium between supply and demand.

componenttext: Gary, we're still looking at that. The different TXI price project should roll off by the end of the year. So I just think we'd have to continue to feather that in I think it's hard to give a percentage on a quarter-to-quarter basis. But so that's something that we will see in varying degrees for 2015. If we're going back to the percentage the percentages that I spoke of, the increases that we're seeing in South Texas are 19%. So I think that does come back and take it that to the degree here.
