componenttext: And my follow-up question if so in that you're to the ticket any coordinate margins in the West Group within the aggregates business. Just wondering if you can provide a little bit of clarity on specifically what is happening in the West Group. And can we realistically see incrementals in the West Group come up to look a lot like of incrementals that you're showing in your other regions?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The short answer is, over time, you can. The West Group story. It was Colorado in January, February and March, which is winter Rockies. And it was really going back to a story in North Texas. If you think about what we are in Texas today after the TXI tra
componenttext: The short answer is, over time, you can. The West Group story. It was Colorado in January, February and March, which is winter Rockies. And it was really going back to a story in North Texas. If you think about what we are in Texas today after the TXI transaction, yes, our position in Houston will support the position at San Antonio supporting position in Austin is supporting. But the North Texas market is the biggest single market that we have that. And when we're looking at the sheer degree of rains that we have the days that we could not work in that marketplace, that's the single biggest driver. Now again, we're seeing pricing move on a percentage basis in the West is better than we are east. That's not a surprise. In large part because it just has more room to go. But what I would say is, one, dry weather is your friend. Pricing is different. But increased efficiencies will continue to be as well. And we think we'll see that. So the incrementals as attractive as the East with immediacy? No, they never really have. Do you think they'll close the gap over time? Yes. And will it close the gap at different speeds in different markets? The answer to that is yes, as well.

There's really not.

componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could talk about within the West Group is where you saw the most dramatic price increases, how broad-based is that? Is that really across the board? And mixed contribution within that? And I guess, when the bulk of the price increases
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could talk about within the West Group is where you saw the most dramatic price increases, how broad-based is that? Is that really across the board? And mixed contribution within that? And I guess, when the bulk of the price increases puts through? And should we get a bigger tailwind in 2Q in that region?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: If you think back to last year, we actually saw mid-years and all of the markets in Texas then we came back and then price increases at the beginning of this year as well work and what I would say, Jerry, and really not go to market by market Texas, but I
componenttext: If you think back to last year, we actually saw mid-years and all of the markets in Texas then we came back and then price increases at the beginning of this year as well work and what I would say, Jerry, and really not go to market by market Texas, but I'll tell you is the lowest one that I'm seeing, even in soft markets, is 10% and others are obviously considerably more attractive than that. So we're seeing good solid pricing across that entire market place, which again I think it's indicative of continued momentum there and a continued, positive outlook. If contractors feel like they're seeing something awfully challenging coming their way, I don't think we would see that type of pricing momentum in every corner of our business in that state. And we were speaking to West Group, I need to pause on Colorado to we're seeing good movement on aggregate pricing in the Colorado market. And again, part of what I believe we're going to see, Jerry, is more of a hard rock and influence coming in the markets north of Denver, simply because they have alluvial place they're playing out. And again, we've got, what I think, is the premier hard rock position in that Denver market. So both in Texas and Colorado, which really defined in many respects the West Group on aggs. That's our advertising pricing right now.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then at times, you put in price increases in April 1 instead of January 1, should we look for a bigger price increase on a year-over-year basis as a result in 2Q in the West Group? Or most price increases effective January 1?
componenttext: And then at times, you put in price increases in April 1 instead of January 1, should we look for a bigger price increase on a year-over-year basis as a result in 2Q in the West Group? Or most price increases effective January 1?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say the majority of them were affected January 1. Frankly, some didn't go in April. But remember, Jerry, it's not usually predicting market Colorado. Not a lot of aggs are moving in January. And so I'm not sure in this instance the timing would've
componenttext: I would say the majority of them were affected January 1. Frankly, some didn't go in April. But remember, Jerry, it's not usually predicting market Colorado. Not a lot of aggs are moving in January. And so I'm not sure in this instance the timing would've made a big a difference. I do still think the overall market and the movement in pricing to me is really -- it's holding, I'll just put it that way.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then philosophically, can you talk about pricing in cement? Some folks are talking about an environmental surcharge of $5 per ton in mid-September. What are your thoughts around that topic? Are you planning something similar?
componenttext: Okay. And then philosophically, can you talk about pricing in cement? Some folks are talking about an environmental surcharge of $5 per ton in mid-September. What are your thoughts around that topic? Are you planning something similar?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We certainly plan to come back and look at what we feel like the price increases need to be for later in the year. I think coming back at some point looking at another $10 a ton is not unrealistic. And I think that's the type of conversation that we're go
componenttext: We certainly plan to come back and look at what we feel like the price increases need to be for later in the year. I think coming back at some point looking at another $10 a ton is not unrealistic. And I think that's the type of conversation that we're going to be having with our customers. Obviously, if you like, Texas will continue to be a sold-out market. And remember the way we're seeing Texas, even would bring on some additional capacity, [indiscernible] about that before, we thought that they've come back in 2014 and add some additional capacity in that state. We're still seeing that Texas is going to be short on domestic supply by almost 3.8 million tons. Keep in mind, last year, they were short on domestic supply by 3.7 million tons. But what we're seeing is actually a tighter market in 2015 there than we saw in 2014. I think a tight market gives you sense of what should happen to pricing.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: What we're seeing right now is steel, the quarter running modestly over 70%. We're still seeing a very good business there. We're seeing a very good chemicals business in particular. Keep in mind, U.S. steel demand grew 13% [ph] in 2014 to 118 million ton
componenttext: What we're seeing right now is steel, the quarter running modestly over 70%. We're still seeing a very good business there. We're seeing a very good chemicals business in particular. Keep in mind, U.S. steel demand grew 13% [ph] in 2014 to 118 million tons compared to 105 million tons in 2013. So with the amount of power manufacturing that we're seeing with the strength that we're seeing in chemicals business and with so the customer relationship that we have, we feel very, very good about where we're sitting Magnesia Specialties.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just as a reminder, Craig, [indiscernible] Magnesia Specialties the product that we need most directly goes into steel. But are actually a purchaser of dolomitic lime to supply our chemicals business. So we do believe that if there is some dislocation tha
componenttext: Just as a reminder, Craig, [indiscernible] Magnesia Specialties the product that we need most directly goes into steel. But are actually a purchaser of dolomitic lime to supply our chemicals business. So we do believe that if there is some dislocation that, we've got room to absorb some of that in our chemicals business.

componenttext: I guess, Ted, what I would say is, you still got, in most markets in Texas, markets that are below our corporate average. And so what I would tell you is you're seeing higher-percentage movement in the West and the east. But my view to have more room in the west to move up higher percentages. So if I'm looking at these percentages, they're a very attractive. If I'm looking at the prices, they're getting candidly to what I'd be like so much acceptable and appropriate level. But I also still believe in a number of those markets. You got a lot of moving ahead of you.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ward, you brought up the [indiscernible] spending budget for this year is $9 billion. Do you have any sense for what that looks like for next year?
componenttext: Ward, you brought up the [indiscernible] spending budget for this year is $9 billion. Do you have any sense for what that looks like for next year?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's going to continue to be strong in large part because look at it in 2 different ways, Adam. Number one, there continue to have $1 billion from [indiscernible] 17 profile. Keep in mind, Texas is a fiscal year that ends in August, not June, so it's diff
componenttext: It's going to continue to be strong in large part because look at it in 2 different ways, Adam. Number one, there continue to have $1 billion from [indiscernible] 17 profile. Keep in mind, Texas is a fiscal year that ends in August, not June, so it's different than many of our states. We got an $8 -- or call it, $9 billion budget this year that's coming on the tail of a couple of the record of DOT budgets in Texas. So what I would tell you is that anybody tells you what they think Texas is going to be next year and the year after is going to be wrong because if we looked at Texas, and we went back 2 or 3 years, and did that same look-forward, we, too, would've been wrong. It's just consistently been better than anyone would have thought. And part of what I find moving what's going on in Texas right now on that $1.1 billion is already been basically dedicated for this year under prop 1. When we come back and look at what that means, it's $85 million in Austin. It's $82 million in Dallas. It's $206 million in Houston, and it's $147 million in San Antonio. So if we think back over the last several years on the part of Texas that was not getting as much infrastructure than some of the others, it was places like San Antonio that now have a toll system and they did 4. And they're good slug from prop 1. So if you're looking at restructuring Texas right now, but our team in Texas would tell me us, "Ward, we've got 2, 3 or 4 years of work ahead of us right now."

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I wanted to ask about the mix between res and nonres. I think, last quarter, you said that you expected nonres to grow a little faster than res. This quarter, you're saying res grow faster than nonres. Just wonder if that's because the res
componenttext: Great. And then I wanted to ask about the mix between res and nonres. I think, last quarter, you said that you expected nonres to grow a little faster than res. This quarter, you're saying res grow faster than nonres. Just wonder if that's because the res outlook went up and the nonres outlook came down a little bit.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, we think about our outlook for nonres to be in the single-digit and for res to be in double-digit growth. So actually from a growth perspective, I think what we're seeing in our forecast is consistent with it. What I would tell you to is the mix
componenttext: Actually, we think about our outlook for nonres to be in the single-digit and for res to be in double-digit growth. So actually from a growth perspective, I think what we're seeing in our forecast is consistent with it. What I would tell you to is the mix of business we have from a pure bucket perspective, let's call it, 45% infrastructure, 30% nonres and 15% res is a pretty normalized percentage. They all need to be lifted up, and that's what we're seeing. But from a pure breakdown of business geographically and end-user across our company and our business, we don't feel bad with those percentages. We're just looking forward to more volume. We think more volume continues to create an enduring good pricing story.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015

componenttext: And your next question comes from Brent Thielman from D. A. Davidson.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ward, your optimism in Texas is crystal clear. But with the inaccuracies of the other energy-exposed regions around the country, it's Oklahoma on the Marcellus and I don't have as much exposure there but are you seeing any evidence of slowing construction
componenttext: Ward, your optimism in Texas is crystal clear. But with the inaccuracies of the other energy-exposed regions around the country, it's Oklahoma on the Marcellus and I don't have as much exposure there but are you seeing any evidence of slowing construction activity in your starts?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes -- I mean, we're not. Do we see some pure slowdown in pure energy that's going on at some of those? Yes, we do. But again from a pure volume perspective, Texas just so much outweighs those and I think the other thing that gives you some optimism about
componenttext: Yes -- I mean, we're not. Do we see some pure slowdown in pure energy that's going on at some of those? Yes, we do. But again from a pure volume perspective, Texas just so much outweighs those and I think the other thing that gives you some optimism about Texas is most shale plays breakeven at the $50 to $60 per barrel. And $50, I think, is a key threshold of pain for a lot of different areas. Texas and what's going on in Eagle Ford is really one of the more competitive areas. So really, one of the most competitive areas of the biggest volume for us is, again, we think back in the 2012 level, that we be relatively attractively. So could there be some headwinds in Niobrara? Maybe. Would there be some headwinds in Marcellus? Maybe. The considerably those are offset by other nonres activity at res? We feel very strongly that it will.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Mike Lutz from Jefferies.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Mike Lutz from Jefferies.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had 2 or 3 quick questions, if I could, please and then the first one to gave I think it was $11 million in Q3 and $10 million in Q4 of expected maintenance spend in Cement. Could you remind me of what it was last year so I've got some idea in terms of
componenttext: I had 2 or 3 quick questions, if I could, please and then the first one to gave I think it was $11 million in Q3 and $10 million in Q4 of expected maintenance spend in Cement. Could you remind me of what it was last year so I've got some idea in terms of modeling? Secondly, we've just received the Texas Cement. It was very weak in March. Could you talk -- have any impact at all trying to put the price increases through [indiscernible] you're presumably people are pretty disappointed by double-digit decline in volumes, which appears to be the case in March. And then thirdly, could you talk about what California volumes did? I don't if you know the figures for the quarter a year ago, but some idea of what the trend in terms of shipments is going on there?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, Mike. But we'll do is we'll talk with you think happens to kiln maintenance because again as outlined Mike, forecast $5.4 million are actually that is what we spent in Q1. $2 million forecasting Q2. $11.2 million in Q3 and $10.3 million in Q4.
componenttext: Absolutely, Mike. But we'll do is we'll talk with you think happens to kiln maintenance because again as outlined Mike, forecast $5.4 million are actually that is what we spent in Q1. $2 million forecasting Q2. $11.2 million in Q3 and $10.3 million in Q4. What we had told you that we did early in the year was around $33.3 million worth of expense for the year. We think we're coming in now with 28.9. So it's going to be about a $4.4 million difference. As a practical matter, just looking at the marketplace is moving. I think the challenge is that you're seeing in Cement those March numbers are more weather and location driven than anything else. I do think West Texas is clearly a very different Cement market than the Smith markets in which we participate. So to the extent of those are almost purely energy driven, we're not going to feel the pain. I think we come back to the notion that we discussed Mike, that is almost on daily mathematics, we see Texas is almost $4 million on domestic supply short this year. So from a pricing perspective, I think you're going to be in fine shape. That doesn't concern me.

But obviously looking to ramp those up, from our investor Alice day. We view as 90% is a world-class number and our aim is to get there.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Martin Marietta First Quarter 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Wa
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Martin Marietta First Quarter 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ward Nye, Chairman and CEO. Mr. Nye, please go ahead.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining Martin Marietta's quarterly earnings call. With me today is Anne Lloyd, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.As announced in this morning's release, we reported the first quarter profit for t
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining Martin Marietta's quarterly earnings call. With me today is Anne Lloyd, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
As announced in this morning's release, we reported the first quarter profit for the first time since 2008, another validation of our recent growth initiatives and cost management programs. Our results reflect aggregates product line volume growth and a double-digit pricing increase, which we achieved despite severe late-winter weather in many markets and significant rainfall in Texas, which we estimate reduced West Group earnings by $13 million or $0.12 per diluted share. The Magnesia Specialties business generated first quarter record net sales and gross profit, and the acquired operations provided a significant contribution to our earnings and cash flow.
Before providing specific comments on the quarter, I'm pleased to tell you that the foundation, position and momentum within our business should translate into strong growth, as we expect to benefit from an environment of increasing demand for construction materials.
As a preparatory reminder, today's conference may include forward-looking statements as defined by securities laws in connection with future events or future operating or financial performance. Like other businesses, we're subject to risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially. Except as legally required, we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether resulting from new information, future developments or otherwise. We refer you to the legal disclaimers contained in our first quarter earnings release and to our other filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which are available on both our own and the SEC websites. Also, any margin references in our discussion are based on net sales and exclude freight and delivery revenues. These and other non-GAAP measures are also explained in our SEC filings and on our website.
Consistent with recent quarters, I'll discuss the results for the heritage business separately from those of the acquired operations, which include the legacy TXI business and 2 other small aggregates product line operations. While it's currently important to consider the results of heritage versus acquired operations so that we're fully transparent with our results and you can analyze and evaluate the quality of our financial performance, this comparison becomes less meaningful as we complete the integration of the TXI operations into our core business. In addition, to facilitate this discussion, we've made available during this webcast and on our website supplemental financial information that presents details of our performance. 
First, as detailed on Slide 2, the heritage Martin Marietta business, which includes Magnesia Specialties, provides a same-on-same comparison to the prior year first quarter. Next, the results of the acquired operations by product line and in total are provided on Slide 4. And finally, on Slide 6, we provide an analysis of the increase in earnings from operations. We believe this approach provides meaningful information to better analyze our current performance.
Now let's review some of the underlying trends for the heritage business. Slide 3 provides volume and pricing metrics by product line for the heritage aggregates business. First, we're pleased to report pricing growth across our entire company. It's important to note that the prior year first quarter includes shipments from 3 facilities in the West Group that were divested in the third quarter of 2014. Consequently, to obtain true comparable volume variances, shipments from these 3 locations should be excluded from the prior year quarter. After making this adjustment, West Group volumes were up slightly, while shipments from the heritage aggregates business increased 7%. Further, and as you are aware, our business is an outdoor undertaking, and weather can disproportionately affect quarterly results, particularly so in the first quarter. On the whole, winter weather was modestly better across our enterprise during the early portion of the quarter as compared to last year. However, Texas precipitation this year was above average, near-record levels, according to the National Climatic Data Center. In fact, we estimate approximately 1.4 million tons of aggregates product line shipments were deferred from the first quarter to the remainder of the year. Heritage West Group aggregate volumes, excluding shipments from the divested operations from the prior year quarter, would've increased approximately 7.5% had we not incurred weather delays. Ready-mixed concrete shipments were reduced by approximately 200,000 cubic yards. Naturally, profitability from these product lines was also negatively affected by lower production and efficiency levels. As previously discussed, we estimate West Group earnings were reduced by up to $13 million during the quarter. Despite these headwinds, our commitment to operational excellence, cost discipline and continued synergy realization from the acquired businesses enabled us to post a very strong quarter.
Aggregates product line growth was led by the infrastructure end-use markets and driven by large projects. Notable growth was experienced in North Carolina and Iowa. This trend coincides with indicators of further recovery in the eastern half of the United States as North Carolina, Georgia and Florida all now ranked in the top 5 states for job growth, a clear stimulus for construction activity. Texas is second in the nation in job growth, and the state Department of Transportation has a fiscal 2015 letting budget of nearly $9 billion. This amount includes funds provided by Texas's proposition 1 constitutional amendment, which addresses needed road repairs, including infrastructure work in South Texas. This amendment is expected to provide over $1 billion per annum for the foreseeable future and, in fact, over $1 billion has already been allocated to specific districts within Texas. This 2015 activity, coupled with an existing backlog, should generate robust infrastructure construction activity over the next several years. Additionally on March 1, 2015, Iowa enacted a $0.10 per gallon increase in state gas tax, which is expected to increase annual infrastructure funding by approximately $215 million. Several other states, including North Carolina and Georgia, are considering additional legislative measures to increase state-level funding.
We're pleased to see states continue to prioritize funding infrastructure initiatives, while Congress deliberates a long-term federal highway bill. The provisions of the Moving Ahead for Progress in the 21st Century Act or MAP-21 have been extended through May 31, and we anticipate another continuing resolution through the fall while Congress works toward passage of a multiyear bill. Shipments to the nonresidential end-use market were up slightly as the economic recovery enters a more construction-centric phase. For us, this market is broadly comprised of 2 components: light and heavy construction. And importantly, we're beginning to see a nascent return to a 50-50 balance between these 2 categories, a normal equilibrium. 
The light nonresidential component is primarily office and retail, and demand of this component is generally tied more directly to residential demand with a 12- to 18-month lag. The heavy component is primarily industrial building and energy, with both direct and energy-related shipments serving this area. The heavy nonresidential end-use market represented 25% of quarterly heritage aggregates volumes, and shipments increased 1% over the prior year quarter. Texas leads the country with $39 billion in nonresidential starts during the trailing 12 months ended March 2015 and billions more expected to be started. Further, diversified state economies have generated other nonresidential and infrastructure projects to replace direct energy sector shipments currently displaced by volatile oil prices. The company expects energy-related construction activity to remain strong, supported by more than $100 billion of planned projects along the Gulf coast, including a significant portion in Texas. The residential end-use market represented 15% of heritage aggregates shipments and increased 4% compared with the prior year quarter. The overall rate of residential growth has slowed compared with the last few years, in part due to an inventory reduction and the availability of unimproved building lots in our markets. We were encouraged to see Georgia, Florida and South Carolina join Colorado in reporting double-digit growth in housing starts for the trailing 12 months through March. This represents yet another sign of recovery in the Eastern United States.
Finally, to conclude discussion of end-use markets for the first quarter, the ChemRock and Rail market represented the remaining 11% of our heritage aggregates volume, and shipments were up slightly compared to the prior year quarter. A positive trend for this end-use is the increasing investment in capacity expansion and maintenance by major railroads, which should lead to higher demand for ballast shipments.
Heritage aggregates product line pricing increased 10.5% over the prior year quarter led by the West Group. Based on what we're expecting for the remainder of the year, we're raising full year aggregates product line pricing guidance from what was a projected increase of 4% to 6% to now an increase of 7% to 9% over our 2014 results. Heritage aggregates product line total production cost per ton shipped remained relatively flat compared with the prior year quarter. We continue to benefit from the decline in diesel prices and, on average, paid $2.04 per gallon compared with $3.18 in the prior year quarter. Heritage aggregates downstream-related product lines increased their combined gross profit by $3 million, primarily driven by the ready-mixed concrete product line, where nearly 11% increase in average selling price led to a 490-basis-point increase in the product line gross margin. Gross profit for the heritage aggregates business increased $27 million and was 9.7% of net sales, an improvement of 730 basis points over the prior year quarter. 
All reportable segments generated a higher gross margin led by an increase of 1,040 basis points in the Southeast Group. Continued economic recovery in Georgia and better performance by our offshore operations contributed to this improvement. Our heritage business generated an incremental gross margin of 76%, besting our incremental margin target of 60%. This performance was led by long-awaited recovery in both the Mid-East and Southeast divisions. We expect continued economic recovery in other geographic areas hardest hit over the past several years.
The Magnesia Specialties business continues its exceptional performance and generated net sales of $58.8 million and a gross profit of $20.2 million, both of which represent first quarter records. For the quarter, the business achieved a gross margin of 34.3%, an increase of 160 basis points over the prior year quarter.
Slides 4 and 5 provide financial information and key metrics for our acquired operations. For the first quarter, the acquired aggregates product line reported net sales of nearly $32 million on external shipments of 2.5 million tons. Average selling price was $12.83 per ton, which reflects the product mix skewed towards higher-priced sand and gravel and rail yard shipments compared to our heritage operations. Despite the negative impact of weather during the quarter, we're pleased to deliver gross margin improvement compared with the performance in the second half of 2014. Our recently acquired ready-mixed concrete business shipped nearly 1 million cubic yards during the quarter at an average selling price of $88.75. This reflects the $6 per cubic yard increase implemented last August in the North Texas market. As a reminder, pricing increases typically have a 6-month lag before full realization. As indicated earlier, weather constraints during the quarter adversely affected operations and reduced the profitability of this business by an estimated $6 million.
The Cement business is benefiting from continued strength in our Texas markets where demand is expected to exceed local supply again this year. However, first quarter operating results were negatively affected by wet weather, which delayed some shipments to the balance of the year. For the first quarter, the business shipped 1 million tons of cement to external customers at an average selling price of $93.41 per ton, resulting in net sales of more than $96 million. The business achieved a gross margin of nearly 20% after incurring $5.5 million of planned kiln maintenance costs. We expect to incur $2 million of some of our costs in the second quarter, with $11 million and $10 million of such expenses in both the third and fourth quarters, respectively. During the first quarter, the company announced a price increase of $10 per ton in the Texas and California markets, effective April 1.
Our consolidated selling, general and administrative or SG&A expenses were 7.8% of net sales, a decline of 120 basis points. This improvement reflects net sales growth outpacing the increase in SG&A, partially offset by higher pension expense. We also incurred net acquisition-related expenses of $1.6 million, which reflects our estimated run rate for the next few quarters.
As detailed on Slide 6, our reported earnings from operations for the quarter of $25.6 million improved $41.5 million from the prior year quarter loss of $15.9 million. Our synergy expectations are consistent with our most recent guidance. We did complete the systems integration for the Cement and ready-mixed concrete businesses during the second quarter, in line with our integration plan. We recorded a small income tax benefit for the quarter, driven by discrete events. However, excluding discrete events, our effective income tax rate would've been 31%, in line with our full year guidance. For the year, we expect to fully utilize allowable net operating loss carryforwards of $363 million, which will reduce cash taxes.
For the quarter, we generated $35 million of operating cash flow compared with $7 million for 2014. The increase is due to higher earnings before depreciation, depletion and amortization expense, partially offset by higher cash taxes paid in the first quarter of 2015 for the 2014 tax year. The ratio of consolidated debt to consolidated EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ended March 31, 2015, was slightly less than 2.5x, in compliance with our leverage covenant and within our targeted range. As a reminder, we have board authorization to repurchase up to 20 million shares of our common stock. We expect to complete the program over the next few years. However, the actual timing will depend on available cash and the market price of our stock during the time frame.
Moving to our full year guidance. We anticipate growth in nearly all of our markets both geographically, particularly in areas with stronger employment gains and construction end-use. Further, we expect economic expansion in the Western United States to continue and, importantly, the economic recovery in the East to accelerate. Overall, in our geographies, we expect growth in our 3 largest end-use markets. Infrastructure market is expected to increase in the mid-single digits. Nonresidential construction is expected to increase in the high single digits. The residential market is expected to experience a double-digit increase, and the ChemRock/Rail market is expected to remain relatively flat. 
Cumulatively, we expect aggregates product line shipments to increase 10% to 12% with 4% to 7% growth in the heritage business and the remainder coming from a full year of owning the TXI operations. Again, we expect aggregates product line pricing to now be up 7% to 9% over 2014. Aggregates product line production cost per ton shipped is expected to decline slightly compared with 2014. The aggregates-related downstream operations are expected to generate between $875 million and $925 million of net sales and $65 million to $70 million of gross profit. We expect net sales for the Cement business to range from $475 million to $500 million and gross profit to be $120 million to $130 million. Magnesia Specialties net sales are expected to be between $240 million and $250 million, generating a gross profit of $85 million to $90 million. SG&A expenses as a percentage of net sales are expected to be less than 6%, despite an $18 million increase in heritage pension costs over 2014. On a consolidated basis, we expect to generate earnings before interest, income taxes, depreciation, depletion and amortization expense or EBITDA ranging from $835 million to $875 million. Interest expense should approximate $75 million to $80 million, and the effective income tax rate is expected to be 31%, excluding discrete events. Capital expenditures are forecast to be $320 million, which includes $35 million of synergy-related capital and $80 million for the continued development of the new Medina limestone quarry outside of San Antonio. This capital project will provide a modern and highly efficient rail-connected quarry capable of shipping products to South Texas, including Houston, for generations.
To conclude, we are very excited about the future of Martin Marietta Materials. Our commitment to core foundational pillars, world-class safety, operational excellence, cost discipline, ethical conduct, sustainability and customer satisfaction, along with the growing demand for construction materials, should lead to improved profitability and allow us to continue to increase shareholder value. 
If the operator will now give the required instructions, we'll turn our attention to addressing your questions.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from Todd Vencil from Sterne Agee.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from Todd Vencil from Sterne Agee.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let's talk about incrementals first. 76% is a pretty good number, I would say. I'm guessing strength in the price increase was a big factor in that. Can you talk about what else went into that?
componenttext: Let's talk about incrementals first. 76% is a pretty good number, I would say. I'm guessing strength in the price increase was a big factor in that. Can you talk about what else went into that?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Part of what you're seeing, Todd, is you're seeing that southeast part of the United States come back a little, but you heard what those incrementals look like in a state like Georgia. So you're entirely right. Does pricing help? Yes, it does. Does cost m
componenttext: Part of what you're seeing, Todd, is you're seeing that southeast part of the United States come back a little, but you heard what those incrementals look like in a state like Georgia. So you're entirely right. Does pricing help? Yes, it does. Does cost management help? Yes, it does. Does geographic mix, where you're starting to see some business come back, help a lot? It does. I mean, let's talk a little bit about what we saw relative to our production analysis just on the cost side. I mean, the pricing side, I think you can see with greater clarity. But if we're looking at total heritage aggregates cost per ton, they declined 17% or 2% after adjusting for increased production volumes. What we did, Todd, is we were able to fully capture a 36% decline per gallon in diesel cost during the quarter, but we saw heritage production volume go up 12% or 2.9 million tons. So what's happening at the end of the day, separate and distinct from what's going on in pricing, is each incremental ton was produced at 20% lower than it was in 2014 from a natural cost per ton. So you're seeing it on both sides of the equation. The pricing, I think, from the release really jumps out and hits you in the face, but I think what's happening on the cost side and what's happening geographically is important in that 76% as well.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's great. And then one other for me, and then I'll give other people a chance to ask a question. But you talked about a pickup in subdivision development. Can you go into that a little more? And is there -- any quantifying you can do around th
componenttext: Got it. That's great. And then one other for me, and then I'll give other people a chance to ask a question. But you talked about a pickup in subdivision development. Can you go into that a little more? And is there -- any quantifying you can do around that or, at least, talk about places where that's strengthening up?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, we're clearly seeing better housing in the east and leasing profile. I mean, here -- housing is completely following the playbook that we thought we'd see. Permits were up 5%. Starts were up 10%. Completions at 12%. But here are the stats that mov
componenttext: I mean, we're clearly seeing better housing in the east and leasing profile. I mean, here -- housing is completely following the playbook that we thought we'd see. Permits were up 5%. Starts were up 10%. Completions at 12%. But here are the stats that move me. Permanents are ahead of starts. Starts are ahead of completions. And even when we're sitting here with those types of metrics, housing still remains well below historical averages. So I think it gives us a great deal of upside. What we're seeing, too, is it's being fueled by employment gains. So if you go back to those states that we outlined in my comments where we're seeing good employment movement, North Carolina, Georgia, South Carolina, Florida, that's what's driving a lot of that. The other thing that I'm moved by, Todd, is a very tepid recovery in housing has really spurred pricing that. So we can imagine what a really good market in housing is going to look like, but that's what we're seeing right now, Todd.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up on that. Am I right to think that subdivision development is sort of a lot steadier and longer-tailed than the more sort of specifically related to lot development or what goes on in the house?
componenttext: And just a follow-up on that. Am I right to think that subdivision development is sort of a lot steadier and longer-tailed than the more sort of specifically related to lot development or what goes on in the house?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It is. One, it's a good early indicator. Two, it's longer-lived. Three, it's more aggregate-intensive. Because remember, Todd, when we talk about res, we're not just talking about the rock going into the lot development. We're talking about the lot going
componenttext: It is. One, it's a good early indicator. Two, it's longer-lived. Three, it's more aggregate-intensive. Because remember, Todd, when we talk about res, we're not just talking about the rock going into the lot development. We're talking about the lot going into the subdivision streets, the subdivision sidewalks, the subdivision utilities. That's part of what drives the comment that I said about moving to a more construction-centric phase of recovery, and that clearly is moving toward more subdivision development. Yes.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Kathryn Thompson from Thompson Research.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Kathryn Thompson from Thompson Research.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question I have is around energy in Texas. Just for practical purposes, the volumes that were impacted by weather, particularly in March, do you view those as delayed or lost? And then the second tag that's related to Texas, could you give more colo
componenttext: First question I have is around energy in Texas. Just for practical purposes, the volumes that were impacted by weather, particularly in March, do you view those as delayed or lost? And then the second tag that's related to Texas, could you give more color on trends that you've seen for shale play-specific volumes? And in your opinion, how's prop 1 -- or will prop 1 be more than enough to offset those volume losses that were going to pad buildout?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Kathryn. Volume loss in Q1 is not gone. It's deferred, and it's deferred to the balance of year. So I feel comfortable we'll capture all of that. And clearly, a lot of that was driven by rain. I mean, I don't want to turn into a weather man here tod
componenttext: Sure, Kathryn. Volume loss in Q1 is not gone. It's deferred, and it's deferred to the balance of year. So I feel comfortable we'll capture all of that. And clearly, a lot of that was driven by rain. I mean, I don't want to turn into a weather man here today, but I look at something to me that I thought was moving on how weather affected, particularly North Texas. If we look at water reservoirs in North Texas a year ago, they were 68% full. If we look at where they were 3 months ago, they were 64% full. And if we look at where they are today, they're 94% full. I mean, that's remarkable rain in North Texas. That's what, among other things, gives me confidence. That volume's been pushed to the right. It's not volume that's gone. What we are seeing in non-res in other parts of Texas continues to be very strong. We feel comfortable that whatever weakness we're seeing in shale energy, yes, will be picked up by housing, and gas will be picked up by other components of non-res. And to answer your question really directly on what we're seeing relative to shale, it's an uneven story. I mean, here's what I see. I see volumes down in the first quarter in Eagle Ford Shale, 31%. I see volumes up in Haynesville, 142%. Now the short answer is do I think they're going to be down overall just pure shale volumes? Yes, I do. But here's my take on it, Kathryn. I think they're going to look a lot like they did in 2012. And in 2012, all rolled in, we sold about 6 million tons to the different shale plays. And when I think back to 2012, number one, everybody liked the way 2012 felt, and nobody really thought they'd be that good. So do we think it'll be back at the 2012 level in '15? We do. Are we seeing uneven movements in some of the plays? We are. Do we think that volume that was lost in Q1 was simply deferred? We do. I think I answered your questions. Is that responsive?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. And then my final follow-up question, just around guidance. Fantastic growth in pricing. Is the conservatism or the factors driving your decision not to raise EBITDA guidance more, is this driven by you saying, "Listen, we just want to be conser
componenttext: Yes, yes. And then my final follow-up question, just around guidance. Fantastic growth in pricing. Is the conservatism or the factors driving your decision not to raise EBITDA guidance more, is this driven by you saying, "Listen, we just want to be conservative."? Or is there any other factor that we should take into consideration for that EBITDA?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: You know what, Kathryn? I guess, what I would say to you is it's April, and pricing was just so strong, honestly. You just had to come back and adjust that. Yes, I talked through on the previous answer what we were looking like on the cost profile, so wha
componenttext: You know what, Kathryn? I guess, what I would say to you is it's April, and pricing was just so strong, honestly. You just had to come back and adjust that. Yes, I talked through on the previous answer what we were looking like on the cost profile, so what I would say to you is the cost profile looks good. The pricing looks good. The geography looks good. And if someone wants to accuse us of being conservative, I'll probably take the accusation.

componenttext: I think along the lines of the -- Kathryn's question, I think I was just wondering if you could provide a little bit more color around the aggregate pricing, in particular. Because if we were to trend the first quarter through the full year, then you would already be on the high end of your guidance. So I know the first quarter can be skewed by low volumes, but do you think that's a good run rate? Or is it just back to that, just seeing how-it-goes kind of approach?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's funny, Timna. If I look across our enterprise, prices are up everywhere, and prices are up everywhere. There's some places that pricing is up over 30%. And obviously, you don't see that everywhere, but that gives you a sense of pricing. It's actually
componenttext: It's funny, Timna. If I look across our enterprise, prices are up everywhere, and prices are up everywhere. There's some places that pricing is up over 30%. And obviously, you don't see that everywhere, but that gives you a sense of pricing. It's actually very strong. And mix in the first quarter did not have a profound effect on what was going on with this. So we do want to let this play out a little bit more. But clearly, when you're seeing volumes ramp up, we're going to see the pricing come behind that.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. So just switching gears to Cement. I'm resting on the topic. And you announced the price hike, you said, for April. You mentioned, specifically, that Texas was tight, so it sounds like that can pass and easily, if I recall, it take
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. So just switching gears to Cement. I'm resting on the topic. And you announced the price hike, you said, for April. You mentioned, specifically, that Texas was tight, so it sounds like that can pass and easily, if I recall, it takes a little bit of time to see that flow through like you mentioned in ready-mixed. Are you as confident on the price increase in California? And is the market tight enough to, perhaps, warrant a further increase? Can you comment on this?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're certainly going to come back, and we're going to look at more increase in Cement pricing as we get into the year. What I can tell you right now, up through Q1, Cement pricing in North Texas was up 11%. And in South Texas, it was up 19%. In Californi
componenttext: We're certainly going to come back, and we're going to look at more increase in Cement pricing as we get into the year. What I can tell you right now, up through Q1, Cement pricing in North Texas was up 11%. And in South Texas, it was up 19%. In California, it was up 15%. So to your point, those are pretty nice percentage moves that we're seeing in pricing in those markets. And again, we're at a leading position in the Texas markets, but even where we have the leading positions, I think it's important. This is not a West Texas Cement play. This is a North Texas and a South Central Texas Cement play. So we continue to feel very confident about where we sit in pricing in those markets.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, so -- just sorry, to clarify those, the California is looking, it sounds like, just as strong as Texas, but I wasn't sure if it's not as tight a market or if it's also looking quite tight?
componenttext: Okay, so -- just sorry, to clarify those, the California is looking, it sounds like, just as strong as Texas, but I wasn't sure if it's not as tight a market or if it's also looking quite tight?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's not -- it is not as tight a market as Texas is. I certainly can see that, and the total pricing isn't, right now, as attractive as it is Texas. But from a percentage perspective, frankly, it's moving somewhere on a percentage perspective between wher
componenttext: It's not -- it is not as tight a market as Texas is. I certainly can see that, and the total pricing isn't, right now, as attractive as it is Texas. But from a percentage perspective, frankly, it's moving somewhere on a percentage perspective between where it is in South Texas and where it is in North Texas right now. And I think that's a good sign for a market moving toward in a very steady-fashion equilibrium between supply and demand.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Garik Shmois from Longbow Research.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Garik Shmois from Longbow Research.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up question on Cement pricing. You indicated that you had a, I think I heard 19% year-over-year growth in North Texas. Just wondering how much of that growth is related to lower-priced projects coming off backlog and being replaced by market
componenttext: Just a follow-up question on Cement pricing. You indicated that you had a, I think I heard 19% year-over-year growth in North Texas. Just wondering how much of that growth is related to lower-priced projects coming off backlog and being replaced by market pricing on current jobs. And also if you could maybe provide a little bit of color on how to think about some of these low-priced TXI projects. How should they roll off as you look into 2015 and what the potential mix benefit would look like over the remaining 3 quarters?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Garik, here's the way I look at that. The different TXI price project should roll off by the end of the year. So I think we'd just have to continue to feather that in throughout the year. I think it's hard to give you a percentage on a quarter-by-quarter
componenttext: Garik, here's the way I look at that. The different TXI price project should roll off by the end of the year. So I think we'd just have to continue to feather that in throughout the year. I think it's hard to give you a percentage on a quarter-by-quarter basis, but -- and that's going to be something that we will see in varying degrees for 2015. It'll be gone at the end of 2015. If you think back to what was going on, on some of those longer-haul cement moves, that was really more of the South Texas issue than it was a North Texas issue. And then if we're going back to the percentage, the percentages that I spoke of, the increases that we're seeing in South Texas are 19%. So I think that does come back and taking time to a degree, Garik.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up question is if there is a need to tick, we think, on the quarter, it would be on incremental margins in the West Group within the aggregates business. Just wondering if you can maybe provide a little bit of clarity on, specifically, what
componenttext: And my follow-up question is if there is a need to tick, we think, on the quarter, it would be on incremental margins in the West Group within the aggregates business. Just wondering if you can maybe provide a little bit of clarity on, specifically, what is happening in the West Group. And can we realistically see incrementals in the West Group come up to look a lot like the incrementals that you're showing in your other regions?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The short answer is, over time, you can. Here's the West Group story. It was Colorado in January, February and March, which is winter in the Rockies. And it was really going back to a story in North Texas. If you think about what we are in Texas today aft
componenttext: The short answer is, over time, you can. Here's the West Group story. It was Colorado in January, February and March, which is winter in the Rockies. And it was really going back to a story in North Texas. If you think about what we are in Texas today after the TXI transaction, yes, our position in Houston is supporting, our position in San Antonio is supporting, our position in Austin is supporting, but the North Texas market is the biggest, single market that we have there. And when we're looking at the sheer degree of rains that we had and the days that we could not work in that marketplace, that's the single, biggest driver. Now again, we're seeing pricing move on a percentage basis in the West better than we are at East. That's not a surprise, in large part, because it just has more room to go. But what I would say is, one, dry weather is your friend. Pricing is your friend, but increased deficiencies will continue to be as well. And we think we'll see that. So will the incrementals in the West be as attractive as the East with immediacy? No, they never really have. Do we think they'll close the gap over time? Yes. And will it close the gap at different speeds in different markets? The answer to that is yes as well.

componenttext: That's really North Texas.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Trey Grooms from Stephens.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Trey Grooms from Stephens.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Drew Lipke on for Trey. My first question just kind of goes back to pricing in the West Group. You saw it up 17%. You mentioned volumes there relatively flat. I'm curious you talked about the Eagle Ford volumes being down 30% there, and I understa
componenttext: This is Drew Lipke on for Trey. My first question just kind of goes back to pricing in the West Group. You saw it up 17%. You mentioned volumes there relatively flat. I'm curious you talked about the Eagle Ford volumes being down 30% there, and I understand ASPs on that business are lower. Can you talk about the mix within that piece and the impact that, that had on pricing overall?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I can, because we went and looked at mix overall in the business. And actually, if anything, mix was a little bit of a headwind for us, not a tailwind for us, oddly enough. I think, in part, because you are seeing increased infrastructure activity in Texa
componenttext: I can, because we went and looked at mix overall in the business. And actually, if anything, mix was a little bit of a headwind for us, not a tailwind for us, oddly enough. I think, in part, because you are seeing increased infrastructure activity in Texas. You are seeing different types of non-res. So you're right, sometimes you're just swapping base for base. So if you're scratching there, and I understand why you would, if you're scratching there to try to find out is there some noise and what's going on from a mix perspective that's either masking or otherwise confusing the pricing story, there's really not. I mean...

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you look at the actual numbers, Drew, it's like 2 basis points. So it's no impact.
componenttext: Yes. If you look at the actual numbers, Drew, it's like 2 basis points. So it's no impact.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, good to hear. And then on the EBITDA guidance, you raised the lower end. I'm curious, you budgeted originally back in October, and you're using October diesel prices at the time. You said diesel is $2.09 in the quarter. So does your current guidance
componenttext: Okay, good to hear. And then on the EBITDA guidance, you raised the lower end. I'm curious, you budgeted originally back in October, and you're using October diesel prices at the time. You said diesel is $2.09 in the quarter. So does your current guidance -- what kind of a diesel impact does that reflect?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're capturing some of that, Drew. Candidly, we're not capturing all of that because none of us are so good to sort out exactly what we think that's going to be for the balance of the year. So again, perhaps there's an element of conservatism in tha
componenttext: Yes. We're capturing some of that, Drew. Candidly, we're not capturing all of that because none of us are so good to sort out exactly what we think that's going to be for the balance of the year. So again, perhaps there's an element of conservatism in that, and we're willing to take that. And again, we'll come back and talk to you more about it when we're back at the half year, but that's really how we're approaching it right now.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Jerry Revich from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Jerry Revich from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could talk about within the West Group is where you saw the most dramatic price increases, how broad-based is that? Is that really across the board? Any mixed contribution within that? And I guess, when were the bulk of the price incr
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could talk about within the West Group is where you saw the most dramatic price increases, how broad-based is that? Is that really across the board? Any mixed contribution within that? And I guess, when were the bulk of the price increases put through? And should we get a bigger tailwind in 2Q in that region?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: If you think back to last year, we actually saw mid-years in all of the markets in Texas. Then we came back, and we had price increases at the beginning of this year as well. And what I would say, Jerry, I really rather not go market by market through Tex
componenttext: If you think back to last year, we actually saw mid-years in all of the markets in Texas. Then we came back, and we had price increases at the beginning of this year as well. And what I would say, Jerry, I really rather not go market by market through Texas, but what I'll tell you is the low -- the lowest one that I'm seeing, even in submarkets, is 10% and others are obviously considerably more attractive than that. So we're seeing good, solid pricing across that entire marketplace, which, again, I think is indicative of continued momentum there and a continued positive outlook. If contractors feel like they're seeing something awfully challenging coming their way, I don't think we would see that type of pricing momentum in every corner of our business in that state. And when we're speaking to West Group, I need to pause on Colorado, too. We're seeing good movement on aggregate pricing in the Colorado market. And again, part of what I believe we're going to see, Jerry, is more of a hard rock and influence coming in to markets north of Denver, simply because they have alluvial place they're playing out. And again, we've got what I think is the premier hard-rock position in that Denver market, so both in Texas and Colorado, which really define, in many respects, the West Group on aggs. That's the story that I see in pricing right now.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then at times, you put in price increases in April 1 instead of January 1, should we look for a bigger price increase on a year-over-year basis as a result in 2Q in the West Group? Or were most price increases effective January 1?
componenttext: And then at times, you put in price increases in April 1 instead of January 1, should we look for a bigger price increase on a year-over-year basis as a result in 2Q in the West Group? Or were most price increases effective January 1?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say the majority of them were effective January 1. Frankly, some did go in, in April. But remember, Jerry, it's not usually predicting markets like Colorado. Not a lot of aggs are moving in January, and so I'm not sure in this instance the timing
componenttext: I would say the majority of them were effective January 1. Frankly, some did go in, in April. But remember, Jerry, it's not usually predicting markets like Colorado. Not a lot of aggs are moving in January, and so I'm not sure in this instance the timing would've made that big a difference. I just still think the overall market and the movement in pricing to me is really -- it's moving. I'll just put it that way.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then philosophically, can you talk about pricing in Cement? Some folks are talking about an environmental surcharge of $5 per ton in mid-September. What are your thoughts around that topic? Are you planning something similar?
componenttext: Okay. And then philosophically, can you talk about pricing in Cement? Some folks are talking about an environmental surcharge of $5 per ton in mid-September. What are your thoughts around that topic? Are you planning something similar?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We certainly plan to come back and look at what we feel like the price increases need to be for later in the year. I think coming back at some point looking at another $10 a ton is not unrealistic, and I think that's the type of conversation that we're go
componenttext: We certainly plan to come back and look at what we feel like the price increases need to be for later in the year. I think coming back at some point looking at another $10 a ton is not unrealistic, and I think that's the type of conversation that we're going to be having with our customers. Obviously, I feel like Texas will continue to be a sold-out market. I mean, the way that we're seeing Texas, even with bringing on some additional capacity, we talked about that before that we thought that we would come back in, in 2014 and add some additional capacity in that state. We're still seeing that Texas is going to be short on domestic supply by almost 3.8 million tons. Keep in mind, last year, they were short on domestic supply by 3.7 million tons. So what we're seeing is actually a tighter market in 2015 there than we saw in 2014. I think a tight market probably gives you a sense of what should happen with pricing.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: If U.S. steel production turns down, does that have an impact on Magnesia Specialties?
componenttext: If U.S. steel production turns down, does that have an impact on Magnesia Specialties?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. What we're seeing right now is steel for the quarter running modestly over 70%. We're still seeing a very good business there. We're seeing a very good chemicals business in particular. Keep in mind, U.S. steel demand grew 13% in 2014 to 118 million
componenttext: Yes. What we're seeing right now is steel for the quarter running modestly over 70%. We're still seeing a very good business there. We're seeing a very good chemicals business in particular. Keep in mind, U.S. steel demand grew 13% in 2014 to 118 million tons compared to 105 million tons in 2013. So with the sheer amount of car manufacturing that we're seeing, with the strength that we're seeing in our chemicals business and with some of the customer relationships that we have, we feel very, very good about where we're sitting in Mag Specialties.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just as a reminder, Craig, dolomitic lime that we produce in Mag Specialties is the product that really most directly goes into steel, but we are actually a purchaser of dolomitic lime to supply our chemicals business. So we do believe that if there is so
componenttext: Just as a reminder, Craig, dolomitic lime that we produce in Mag Specialties is the product that really most directly goes into steel, but we are actually a purchaser of dolomitic lime to supply our chemicals business. So we do believe that if there is some dislocation there, we've got room to absorb some of that in our chemicals business.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Craig, the other element that's important, separate and distinct with the steel is what's happening with the energy there. And actually, what we saw was natural gas prices for our kilns come down pretty considerably Q1 last year to Q1 this year. We saw th
componenttext: Craig, the other element that's important, separate and distinct with the steel is what's happening with the energy there. And actually, what we saw was natural gas prices for our kilns come down pretty considerably Q1 last year to Q1 this year. We saw that come down about 30%, and we feel like that's going to stay at a pretty good steady number for the balance of the year.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The last one. With ready-mixed, you have room to go and ahead and the take price there coincidentally with the Cement price increase.
componenttext: The last one. With ready-mixed, you have room to go and ahead and the take price there coincidentally with the Cement price increase.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, again -- and again, I think that's going to be a market-by market phenomena because you're going to see very different prices, depending on whether you're in Denver or whether you're in Dallas or, frankly, even if you're in some community relatively
componenttext: Well, again -- and again, I think that's going to be a market-by market phenomena because you're going to see very different prices, depending on whether you're in Denver or whether you're in Dallas or, frankly, even if you're in some community relatively close to Dallas but outside of the metroplex. So that's going to be a submarket-by-submarket decision. But if Cement is going up, ready-mixed is going to go up.

componenttext: Primarily, it's the cost increase production volume. As Ward indicated earlier, production volume is up about, what, 12% for the quarter, and so you've got cost -- you've got cost just increasing from the sheer number of tons you're producing.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The other issue that's there, Ted, just to be clear, we did pull some maintenance or repair forward, and we did have some additional stripping in the quarter as well because we're anticipating a heavy-volume year. So we accelerated a little bit of that, w
componenttext: The other issue that's there, Ted, just to be clear, we did pull some maintenance or repair forward, and we did have some additional stripping in the quarter as well because we're anticipating a heavy-volume year. So we accelerated a little bit of that, we believe, but I think those are probably your primary drivers that Anne outlined.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, on a similar note, just some other questions. I know you're seeing pricing is up 29, negative 10.5 points or so year-on-year. And I'm -- just the way you reflect it, it looks like that's all true economic capture of pricing. So I
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, on a similar note, just some other questions. I know you're seeing pricing is up 29, negative 10.5 points or so year-on-year. And I'm -- just the way you reflect it, it looks like that's all true economic capture of pricing. So I guess, I come back to the question, if you flow through an extra 300 basis points, so it's $30 million to $45 million of incremental EBITDA. I know there's a conservatism, but I mean, is there anything else we need to be aware of that has led you to -- I mean, just logically, if you left all other aspects of your guidance unchanged as you did in the press release and you flow through $30 million to $45 million of EBITDA, it's just hard to understand why we're keeping the numbers flat -- or about $10 million at the low end, excuse me.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Ted, look, I hear you. I mean, it -- the only thing I can say is it's still April, and I think just changing a full year EBITDA numbers on -- last time I checked, the EBITDA numbers that people thought were pretty healthy EBITDA numbers. Just didn't f
componenttext: No. Ted, look, I hear you. I mean, it -- the only thing I can say is it's still April, and I think just changing a full year EBITDA numbers on -- last time I checked, the EBITDA numbers that people thought were pretty healthy EBITDA numbers. Just didn't feel right in March, April. And as I said, we can come back and revisit that here in the next quarter, but we just felt like until we had one more quarter in our belt, so let's just watch this.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
